Report that government forces killed two people in Yei county, including a local church person and the head teacher of Nyei primary school, looted a church, and fired at and burnt a market, forcing dozens of people to flee to neighbouring countries.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Nhialdiu. Machars forces denied claims that they abducted 21 aid workers (including one Gambian national) after clashes the town and released them a few days later. Other reports confirmed that the abducted staff from International Rescue Committee, Danish Refugee Council and Mercy Corps returned to the town on 15 November.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Xinhua; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Nhialdiu. Machars forces denied claims that they abducted 21 aid workers (including one Gambian national) after clashes the town and released them a few days later. Other reports confirmed that the abducted staff from International Rescue Committee, Danish Refugee Council and Mercy Corps returned to the town on 15 November.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO forces clashed with SPLA forces in Gadiang in Jonglei on 11 and 14 November, leaving at least six killed, including three civilians and three SPLA soldiers, and thousands of heads of cows stolen.
Looting: Unknown group looted Anisa FM radio station managed by the Catholic Church in Yambio, Western Equatoria region.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.
Suspected Murle tribesmen led by Gen Kali Burtor abducted two children in Nyikani area (Owello Payam) of Pochalla North County.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.

SPLA arrested and detained an aid worker and one of his relatives after leaving their house in Hai Mouna in Juba. The aid worker reportedly died in detention after spending four days without food and water and being thrown in a container.
Unknown gunmen killed a civilians in Wau.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: At least eight prisoners were killed as they tried to escape Rumbek central prison. The remaining three prisoners managed to escape.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column16: Xinhua; Sudan Tribune; PR Newswire; Radio Tamazuj
column17: Clashes between rebels supporting Machar and rebels supporting his successor Taban Deng Gai in Nhialdiu in Unity state. Forces supporting Machar briefly captured and looted the town but were reportedly driven out by the other rebels backed by state forces. Some shops and homes, as well as a humanitarian camp were looted and burnt in the area, forcing 19 aid workers to be relocated and dozens of people to flee after the clashes.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Looting: Suspected SPLA-IO-allied youth militia looted and burnt around 40 huts in Koch.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column16: Sudan Tribune; Gurtong Trust; Radio Tamazuj
column17: Arrests: NSS members arrested and dismissed a government advisor in the newly created Tonj state of Bahr el Ghazal for meeting opposition leader Machar last April. The official said he was implementing a call by President Kiir to lead reconciliation and forgiveness and denounced mistreatment in detention. Several other officials were dismissed later in the week, such as the information minister and Ezo county commissioner in Gbudue state, the undersecretary at the ministry of humanitarian affairs in Juba, and three ministers from Gok state.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.
Gunmen ambushed a vehicle traveling from Juba to Pibor, injuring at least three people.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO rebels ambushed a military vehicle along the Juba-Bor road near al-Mohandisin Bridge, killing 12 government soldiers and destroying the vehicle. The attack was in retaliation for recent killings in Pibor.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Xinhua; Sudan Tribune; PR Newswire
column17: Clashes between rebels supporting Machar and rebels supporting his successor Taban Deng Gai in Nhialdiu in Unity state. Forces supporting Machar briefly captured and looted the town but were reportedly driven out by the other rebels backed by state forces. Some shops and homes, as well as a humanitarian camp were looted and burnt in the area, forcing 19 aid workers to be relocated and dozens of people to flee after the clashes.
SPLA soldiers raped and killed a displaced girl near the UN mission compound in Wau as she had left to get firewood. Three soldiers were later arrested in relations to the incident.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO forces clashed with SPLA forces in Gadiang in Jonglei on 11 and 14 November, leaving at least six killed, including three civilians and three SPLA soldiers, and thousands of heads of cows stolen.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.
Clashes between Maban community and Sudanese refugees from Blue Nile in Maban in November left at least 12 killed from the host community.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Opposition claims to have captured the town of Kaljak after fighting against government forces. Government forces denied the claims.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Opposition claims to have captured the town of Morobo after fighting against government forces. Government forces denied the claims.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Opposition claims to have captured the town of Bazi after fighting against government forces. Government forces denied the claims.
Unverified reports of at least 50 children abducted and recruited into unknown armed forces/groups in the Greater Bahr El Ghazal region in November. In total, 1,300 children were recruited in 2016.
Report of frequent attacks in November by armed opposition groups on teachers and pupils in Bangolo county, Mundri west. At least five schools were forced to shut down.

During the month of November 2016, suspected gunmen from the disputed Northern Liech state (likely to be of Bul Nuer ethnicity) attacked Dany village in the disputed Tuoch county in the eastern half of the disputed Ruweng state in the former Pariang county (Unity state). One person was killed.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.
Gunmen killed a political adviser for South Sudan's proposed Lol State government at his house in Wau after clashing with him and his bodyguard. Authorities later arrested one injured suspect.
At least 50 children abducted and recruited into unknown armed forces/groups in the Greater Upper Nile region in November. In total, 1,300 children were recruited in 2016.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between South Sudanese soldiers and rebels inTore, Central Equatoria, leaving at least 23 killed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between South Sudanese soldiers and rebels as rebels were spotted stealing cattle in Adaab el Bahr village in Unity State, leaving at least 10 killed, including one SPLA and nine rebels. Rebels put the number at 20.
Militia killed two people in an attack to raid cattle in Tali County in Terekeka State. Some cattle was recovered soon after.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.
Gunmen killed two cattle keepers on their way to Manyiel cattle camp in Rumbek to look for grazing areas for their cattle in the week of 14 November.
Suspected youth gunmen from Durbar ambushed a vehicle in Pachuok area of Rumbek East in the week of 14 November, leaving a head master killed and two passengers wounded.

SPLA raped a number of women outside the Bentiu IDP camp on the day of the visit by the UN Independent Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan mid-November as well as a woman in Leer three days prior to their visit. The Commission denounced the use of rape as a tool used by armed groups and government forces for ethnic cleansing, having reached ""epic"" proportions throughout the country since the renewed clashes in Juba in July.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition troops in Li-rangu in Yambio forced hundreds of people to flee.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Ambushes by rebels suspected to be allied to SPLA-IO on Duk county of Jonglei state between 11-19 November left at least 25 people killed, 17 injured and 2,100 herds of cattle raided. Three government officials were ambushed and killed on 19 November by the rebels.

SPLA raped a number of women outside the Bentiu IDP camp on the day of the visit by the UN Independent Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan mid-November as well as a woman in Leer three days prior to their visit. The Commission denounced the use of rape as a tool used by armed groups and government forces for ethnic cleansing, having reached ""epic"" proportions throughout the country since the renewed clashes in Juba in July.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Arrests: SPLA security services arrested the Zande communities paramount chief in Yambio (who also represents all chiefs in Western Equatoria) for unclear reasons. He was released a month later, on 17 December, over deteriorated health.

Primary and secondary school teachers in Jonglei state protested delays from the Ministry of Finance to implement salary incements. Two of them were arrested by security agents a week later, sparking new protests. The teachers have been on strike for two months and have threatened to resign after 11 members suspected of fueling the strike were suspended by the state Ministry of Education.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 22 November a helicopter arrived in Nassir with supplies for the Government Forces garrison. It was accompanied by two helicopter gunships which bombarded SPLM/A-IO positions south of the Sobat River. This led to a heavy exchange of fire. Further firing was heard later that day to the west of Nassir.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA takes control of Dablual in Unity after two days of clashes with opposition forces.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA takes control of Dablual in Unity after two days of clashes with opposition forces.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 25 November there was a significant clash between Government and SPLM/A-IO forces. This apparently happened because the Government Forces took 63 cattle from civilians who crossed the Sobat in the area of Nassir town. In the afternoon about 100 armed civilians and SPLM/A-IO soldiers were seen advancing towards Nassir from the east before withdrawing. Clashes continued on 26 November.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 25 November there was a significant clash between Government and SPLM/A-IO forces. This apparently happened because the Government Forces took 63 cattle from civilians who crossed the Sobat in the area of Nassir town. In the afternoon about 100 armed civilians and SPLM/A-IO soldiers were seen advancing towards Nassir from the east before withdrawing. Clashes continued on 26 November.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: Report that SPLA forces and SPLA-IO forces allied to vice president Taban Deng Gai attacked Dablual and Male villages in Unity state over two days, leaving 20 civilians killed and homes burned down.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.

Unknown gunmen attacked Nabiapai market in Yambio, Western Equatoria, firing gunshots, abducting people, looting property, and setting fire to shops and vehicles. SPLA forces exchanged fire with the group but no arrest were made as they headed towards DRC.

Unknown gunmen attacked Nabiapai market in Yambio, Western Equatoria, firing gunshots, abducting people, looting property, and setting fire to shops and vehicles. SPLA forces exchanged fire with the group but no arrest were made as they headed towards DRC.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (South Sudan)
column17: Looting: Unknown armed group loots the MSF house in Mundri following an assessment of the medical needs in Mundri and surrounding areas a few weeks ago. All activities of the organisation were suspended after the incident.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period.

column17: Report that SPLA forces and SPLA-IO forces allied to vice president Taban Deng Gai attacked Dablual and Male villages in Unity state over two days, leaving 20 civilians killed and homes burned down.
Looting: Report that government forces looted and burned down homes and properties in Nhialdiu and Leer region of Unity in the context of clashes with the opposition in the area.

66 cases of violence against humanitarian personnel/assets between 1-28 November in South Sudan. An additional 26 incidents of interference in humanitarian action through bureaucratic impediments and illegal or arbitrary taxation expulsion of staff. This includes the deportation by South Sudanese authorities of two international NGO staff and the shutting doown of the Juba-based office of one of the largest South Sudanese national NGOs.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.
Looting: Report that government forces looted and burned down homes and properties in Nhialdiu and Leer region of Unity in the context of clashes with the opposition in the area.

column16: AP; UNMISS; South Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune
column17: Movement of forces: Report that the government has mobilised at least 4,000 militia members in Equatoria and deployed new military battallions in and around Juba in preparations for ""large-scale"" attacks in the coming weeks as the dry season begins in South Sudan. Kiirs government denied the accusations but ackowledged activity in the region resulting from soldiers two-year rotation.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between opposition and government forces in Ayachi county in Farajok area of Eastern Equatoria, leaving 28 government soldiers killed and two on the rebels side. SPLA-IO reportedly captured the area.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.

Report that SPLA and armed civilian Dinkas conducted targeted killings, lootings, arbitrary arrests and detentions as well as harassment of civilians between mid-Novemebr and mid-December, in areas that are believed to have been used as passage by opposition forces during the 10 November 2016 attack on Yambio town.
Heavy shooting reported in Rumbek that lasted for about an hour. No casualty.

Primary and secondary school teachers in Bor, Jonglei state marched to the police station to protest the arrest of fellow teachers following recent demonstrations. Police detained 75 teachers initially, but ultimately kept 30 in detention. They were sentenced two weeks later to one month imprisonment and a fine of 1,000 SSP. Teachers in Jonglei have been on strike for two months over delays from the Ministry of Finance to implement salary incements.
Unidentified gunmen raped a woman at gunpoint in Al-Salam residential area of Wau town end November/early December.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces killed at least 11 people in northern South Sudan over 25 November - 2 December. Clashes were notably reported to have continued in Nhiladu and Leer regions of Unity during this period and in Upper Nile.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Change to armed group: Over 300 SPLA forces defected to SPLA-IO led by Machar in Mayom over the governments inability to establish cantonment sites in Equatoria and to feed them. SPLA command denied the claim.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Aid Workers (South Sudan); Health Workers (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: SPLA-IO gunmen ambushed an ambulance carrying ACROSS aid workers along the Lasu-Yei road as they were bringing sick refugees from Nyori camp, wounding the driver, abducting the two health workers and a Congolese refugee, and burning the vehicle. They were released a week later, on 11 December.
Between 2 and 4 December, SPLA fired mortar rounds into Goja and Mugo villages in Yei as they accused residents of supporting SPLA-IO. At least one civilian was confirmed killed.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune; National Courier
column17: Suspected Murle militiamen killed two women and abducted two children in Jalle area in Jonglei state.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO claims to have captured Lasu, Libago, Kagelu, Umbasi and Pakula areas in Yei river state in three days of clashes with government soldiers, whom responded with air and ground attacks. 16 soldiers were reportedly killed in Lasu and Libago in the first two days, while a number of soldiers fled across the border to neighboring DRC. Many more people were reportedly killed in the air and ground attacks on other areas in Yei. SPLA denied that they had lost territory in the clashes.

A militiaman in military trousers killed a mentally ill civilian in Wau town. The reason is unclear.

column9: Government of South Sudan (2011-); Private Security Forces (South Sudan)
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency
column17: SPLA-IO gunmen abducted the Commissionner of newly created Kangapo County, along with three of his security guards and a car driver in Buri, Yei River state, while attending a funeral service.

Agreement: The Dinka and Murle tribes of Jonglei and Boma states signed a peace agreement at the Pibor peace conference to stop hostilities between the two tribes. The deal included clauses putting an end to child abductions, cattle raiding, revenge killings and hate speech. It was endangered by several attacks by Murle militiamen in Jonglei in the days that followed.
Between 2 and 4 December, SPLA fired mortar rounds into Goja and Mugo villages in Yei as they accused residents of supporting SPLA-IO. At least one civilian was confirmed killed.

Inter-communal clashes between the Panawur and Panaguong sections of the Dinka tribe left at least two killed and three injured at Makuac cattle camp in Duony County, near Cueibet. The clash was due to unresolved revenge killings in July.
Unknown gunmen ambushed a vehicle on the Juba-Yei road occupied by several passengers. The vehicle was set on fire, and the passengers taken to an unknown destination.
Gunmen from Rumbek in Western Lakes State raided a cattle camp in Abiriu in Lakes state, leaving at least four people killed, two others wounded, and over 500 cattle raided.
Unidentified gunmen killed a civilian in Gudele area of Juba, causing panic among residents. Reasons are unclear.

Clash between Dinka herders and suspected Murle cattle raiders in Baping village in Jonglei, leaving three Murle men killed.

column8: Rup Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Inter-communal violence between the Rup and Darbur youth in Dhiakkuei, Bhar Naam and Malek Agok areas of Rumbek East left at least 12 people killed and 15 others wounded.

column8: Rup Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Inter-communal violence between the Rup and Darbur youth in Dhiakkuei, Bhar Naam and Malek Agok areas of Rumbek East left at least 12 people killed and 15 others wounded.
Suspected SPLA officers executed at least six people outside of Yambio whom they suspected of being rebels, and burned huts near the bodies early December.

column8: Rup Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Inter-communal violence between the Rup and Darbur youth in Dhiakkuei, Bhar Naam and Malek Agok areas of Rumbek East left at least 12 people killed and 15 others wounded.
A gunman in uniform killed the wife of a local chief in Wau town.
Suspected Murle militiamen killed two people and abducted a child in Kongor village in Jonglei state.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO claims to have captured Lasu, Libago, Kagelu, Umbasi and Pakula areas in Yei river state in three days of clashes with government soldiers, whom responded with air and ground attacks. 16 soldiers were reportedly killed in Lasu and Libago in the first two days, while a number of soldiers fled across the border to neighboring DRC. Many more people were reportedly killed in the air and ground attacks on other areas in Yei. SPLA denied that they had lost territory in the clashes.
Agreement: Chol Lam, former office manager of the former Secretary General of the ruling SPLM returned from exile to join the peace process with the South Sudanese government.
One person killed by communal militia in Abiriu while on his way to his cattle camp.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO announces having captured Ombachi village in Otogo Payam in Yei, killing dozens of SPLA soldiers in the fight and stealing weapons.

Agreement: Governors of Western and Eastern Lakes States signed a peace and reconciliation agreement in Rumbek, agreeing on a number of issues including the comprehensive and forceful disarmament of civil population, the immediate apprehension of criminals, the return of looted cattle to rightful owners and the strengthening the community police.
Suspected Murle tribesmen stabbed a woman and abducted two girls in Neum area, Pochalla North County.
Suspected Murle militiamen killed three people and stole 2,162 cattle in Gadiang.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column16: Radio Tamazuj; UNOCHA; South Sudan News Agency
column17: Arrests: Members of the South Sudanese NSS detained and expelled two members of the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), including the country director and another senior staff of the organisation, on 8 and 13 December. On 6 December, an American journalist working for the Associated Press was also deported to Uganda over his work. He was known for his extensive coverage of human rights violations in the country.
Police shot and killed five members of a family in Kuajok town, Gogrial State. The motive is unclear. He then surrendered himself to authorities.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 9 December there was an exchange of fire between Government and SPLM/A-IO forces to the west of Nasir town. The Government Forces commander claimed that the SPLM/A-IO had initiated the engagement by opening fire on his positions from south of the Sobat River.

Suspected SPLA soldiers harassed a South Sudanese aid worker, stealing his mobile phone at gunpoint in front of residents in rock city in Juba. Soon afterwards, they shot and killed a man in his house after robbing him.
Additional five people killed by commual militias in Cueibet area in the week of 5 December in the context of cattle raids.
Masked gunmen gang-raped a woman in Al-Salam residential of Wau town.

""Armed gunmen ambushed a local NGO vehicle on the Juba-Maridi road and hijacked their car, stole their belongings and shot one of the female national staff members who was later med-evac'd to a hospital in order to receive medical treatment.""
Looting: Jonglei militiamen raided 540 herds of cattle from civilians at gunpoint in Lori Payam, Kajo-Keji County. They drove the cattle towards Juba.
A grenade explosion in Mauna area of Juba left seven people wounded including four severely. Context of the explosion is unclear.

column9: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Arrests: Reports that SPLA arrested two commanders of the Sudanese JEM forces and a general commander of the Sudanese SLM/A-Nur faction on its territory after failing to comply with a recent ultimatum to leave South Sudan. No further information on place and date of arrest. South Sudanese authorities denied the claim.
Revenge clashes between Pagoor and Akaak communal militias in Mayath, Lakes state, left one person killed and two others wounded on both sides.

column17: SPLA and SPLA-IO forces led by Deng Gai reportedly attacked SPLA-IO's Machar positions in Koch and Mayendit Counties between 12 and 18 December, which resulted in at least 14 civilians killed and the looting of civilian property.

At least two people killed, a woman in Loloro area and a farmer, by unidentified gunmen in two separate incidents in the week of 12 December in Torit county.
Gunmen opened fire on a commercial vehicle near Male area in Guit county, leaving nine people killed and 10 others wounded.

A 40-year-old man was shot and killed and his two children abducted at Tedo Payam in Pochalla North County by gunmen believed to be from the Murle tribe.
An attack on a civilian area by suspected Murle cattle raiders is repulsed by locals

Suspected Murle militiamen attacked Pinychuer in twic central county, killing one person and stealing cattle. Clashes ensued later on between the assailants and security forces to recover the stolen cattle, leaving three Murle militiamen killed.

Suspected Murle militiamen attacked Pinychuer in twic central county, killing one person and stealing cattle. Clashes ensued later on between the assailants and security forces to recover the stolen cattle, leaving three Murle militiamen killed.

column16: National Courier; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 14 December 2016, clashes between suspected Murle militiamen who had come to raid a cattle camp and local youth in Jalle payam, Bor county. A total of 28 people were killed, including 11 of the attackers and 17 from Jalle The militiamen stole over 12,000 heads of cattle from the residents.

Gunmen ambushed a lorry on his way from Nimule (Uganda) to Juba, near Magwi, leaving an Ethiopian citizen killed.
Looting: Uniformed armed men raided 998 cattle in Liwolo County of Kajo-Keji region between 13 and 16 December. No injuries or fatalities reported from the raid.
Report of armed clashes between unknown groups in Terekaka town in December, forcing aid workers to be relocated.

column6: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: Non-violent activity: The UN Security Council renewed UNMISS for another year and expanded its mandate, deciding that the mission shall use all necessary means to deter and prevent sexual violence within its capacityand ""monitor, investigate and report incidents of hate speech in the country. The mission will also maintain a troop ceiling of 17,000, including a 4,000-strong Regional Protection Force (RPF).
Unidentified gunmen attacked a vehicle traveling from Juba to Torit at Khordilep, about 24 km from Torit, setting the vehicle on fire and killing 8 of the 11 passengers.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Change to armed group: The Deputy Minister for Labour and Public Service resigned from his post citing lack of political will on the part of President Kiir and members of his administration to implement the 2015 peace agreement, and declared allegiance to the SPLA-IO.

On 17 December, one South Sudan National Police Service officer and a child were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Magwi, while a number of SPLA soldiers were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Torit town.

On 17 December, one South Sudan National Police Service officer and a child were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Magwi, while a number of SPLA soldiers were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Torit town.

column17: The SPLA-IO claimed that they captured Busseri area from the government forces. No fatalities mentioned

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: the SPLA-IO forces attacked Shamedi area in the east of Renk County, but government forces repulsed the attackers, claiming they killed about five opposition soldiers.

column6: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
column8: SSNLM: South Sudan National Liberation Movement
column17: South Sudan People's Patriotic Front elements reportedly attacked a military post at Bazungua in Yambio County, killing two government-aligned South Sudan National Liberation Movement soldiers.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA and SPLA-IO forces led by Deng Gai reportedly attacked SPLA-IO's Machar positions in Koch and Mayendit Counties between 12 and 18 December, which resulted in at least 14 civilians killed and the looting of civilian property.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO forces attack the Kadiba area of Mundri county but are repulsed by the government. Several rebel fighters killed.
At least three people including two children were killed and 21 others wounded in an ambush by unknown gunmen along the Mangala-Pibor road.

Towards the end of December 2016, about 50 suspected SPLA soldiers entered an IDP compound in Yei County. Four soldiers raped a young displaced woman in front of her family while other soldiers cheered. When the woman tried to resist, one of the men threatened to kill her. The armed men then looted possessions and livestock. They tied three members of the victim's family together as well as two neighbours and took them away from the compound. Their corpses were later found near a stream.
At least one person has been confirmed dead and several others sustained injurieswhen a passenger vehicle travelling from Juba to Labonok on Juba-Nimule road came under attack by unknown gunmen

column9: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
column17: Arrests: eight senior officials from two factions of Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) led by Abdel Wahid Mohammed Nur and Minni Arko Minnawi, Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) and SPLM-North were placed under house arrest in Juba after failing to leave South Sudan.
Two policemen open fire on civilians at a social gathering organized by the Awan County Commissioner in Akon area in South Sudan's Gogrial State. Injuries but no fatalities reported.
15 people are killed by unidentified gunmen over a week in Torit county.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Further exchanges of fire between government and SPLA-IO forces to the east of Nasir on 22 December. SPLM/A-IO forces allegedly opened fire on Government soldiers who had gone fishing.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: NSS arrested six Sudanese refugees working as traders in Maban over allegedly transporting goods without paying taxes. One trader attempted to escape and the security forces reacted, beating him to death. This is believed to have sparked wider clashes in the days that followed.
A displaced woman was shot and killed by an unknown gunman after leaving the UN camp in Malakal town in South Sudan's Eastern Nile State

Sudanese refugees from Blue Nile allegedly killed a local militia leader and burnt down his home in Maban, reacting to the killing of a Sudanese refugee trader by government forces on 22 December. This sparked wider violence in the days that followed between the local and refugee communities.
A police officer was shot and killed at his home during a nighttime attack by unknown gunmen in Hai Al-Motamadiya in Wau town on Christmas Eve.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Clashes between NSS police officers deployed to ensure security in Yei and SPLA-affiliated armed group on the Yei-Maridi road (2km from Yei), resulting in the death of two pro-government soldiers.

Maban Defense Force attacked Doro refugee camp on December 24 for unclear reasons. The refugees (from Blue Nile in Sudan) and the Maban community clashed over the next two days. The violence over 24-26 December left around 32 people dead. The number is disputed however, with some sources putting the number around 70. As of February, 50 refugees were still missing and unaccounted for.

Maban Defense Force attacked Doro refugee camp on December 24 for unclear reasons. The refugees (from Blue Nile in Sudan) and the Maban community clashed over the next two days. The violence over 24-26 December left around 32 people dead. The number is disputed however, with some sources putting the number around 70. As of February, 50 refugees were still missing and unaccounted for.
In an attack in Jonglei on 25 December, armed men shot seven civilians dead and wounded two others in Baping village, Twic East County.
On 25 December 2016, SPLA soldiers killed a civilian near Kanjoro River, Yei County, as he was driving his motorbike, transporting bags of charcoal.

At least seven people including women have been killed and several others wounded in a Christmas Day attack on Bapiny village in Twic Centre County by unknown assailants. Local residents managed to kill two attackers during clashes between the two sides.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 26 December there were heavy clashes between Government and SPLM/A-IO forces. About 100 Government soldiers and three vehicles were seen advancing from their base, past the UNMISS base and towards the SPLM/A-IO positions in Kedbeck to the east of Nassir. Heavy fighting was heard.

Maban Defense Force attacked Doro refugee camp on December 24 for unclear reasons. The refugees (from Blue Nile in Sudan) and the Maban community clashed over the next two days. The violence over 24-26 December left around 32 people dead. The number is disputed however, with some sources putting the number around 70. As of February, 50 refugees were still missing and unaccounted for.
On 26 December 2016, a group of SPLA soldiers shot a civilian who was transporting charcoal by motorbike to Yei town.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO forces detained the government-appointed Panyijar County Commissioner after he landed in Ganyiel. The pro-Machar opposition later claimed that he had defected.
Clashes continue between Maban locals and Blue Nile refugees and SPLM-N troops. No fatalities reported.

column6: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
column17: Suspected SSPPF members ambushed an SPLA convoy at Rimenze Boma, north-east of Yambio town, leaving 2 SPLA soldiers killed.
On 28 December 2016, militias associated with SPLA killed a man at Mongon, Ombachi, 27 kilometres from Yei town as he was carrying a machete for cultivation.
unknown gunmen attack a convoy of Ugandan and South Sudanese trucks resulting in one death and multiple severe injuries.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: Agreement:Three army generals have defected from the opposition faction of the Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (SPLM-IO) led by Riek Machar to the pro-government faction led by First Vice-President Taban Deng

The Governor of Lol, one of South Sudans newly created states, narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by unidentified gunmen near Raja. There are no injuries from the exchange of fire between the gunmen and the governors escorts.
15 people were reportedly killed in fighting between Belle youth from Bahr Gel Payam and Gok youth from Cueibet County in Lakes state.
gunmen raid a village near Torit and are pushed back by locals.
A fisherman was reported killed and another survived after an attack carried out by suspected Murle tribesmen at Ajwara area in Pochalla
SPLA forces allegedly killed 8 civilians in the Rimenze area between 1-3 January.
five people were killed in separate incidents of cattle raiding in Northern Liech State at the beginning and the middle of the week
Unknown gunmen attacked a vehicle carrying people at Khor Langa area along the Juba-Yei road , resulting in 7 deaths.

At least two people have been killed and six others are wounded after a public bus carrying passengers came under attack some 20 minutes' drive from Torit town. Gunmen fire indiscriminately at the bus before retreating into the bush.
SPLA forces allegedly killed 8 civilians in the Rimenze area between 1-3 January.
SPLA soldiers allegedly detained two civilians in the Yei area, who were later found dead.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: Suspected SPLA-IO forces clashed with SPLA along the Torit-Juba road, west of Torit town, killing three SPLA soldiers and injuring two others. On the same day, suspected SPLA-IO elements also attacked a prison facility along the Torit-Magwi road, south-west of Torit town, leaving six prison guards missing.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO soldiers in several areas of Nasser on 2 January. Government forces attacked and took Ketbek. They also attacked northeast towards Kuatt, north towards Haimajak and reportedly east towards Ebone. The fighting resulted in homes looted and razed, damaged UNMISS property (accommodation containers and an armoured personal carrier) and forced displacement of around 33,000 people. No mention of fatalities.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO soldiers in several areas of Nasir on 2 January. Government forces attacked and took Ketbek. They also attacked northeast towards Kuatt, north towards Haimajak and reportedly east towards Ebone. The fighting resulted in homes looted and razed, damaged UNMISS property (accommodation containers and an armoured personal carrier) and forced displacement of around 33,000 people. No mention of fatalities.
SPLA forces allegedly killed 8 civilians in the Rimenze area between 1-3 January.

column16: UNSC; International Crisis Group; Radio Tamazuj
column17: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and Agwelek forces in northern Manyo county over 3-4 January. NDM claims to have killed more than 25 Agwelek forces while Agwelek claims to have killed 37 NDM, including two generals.

column8: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
column17: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

column8: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
column17: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

column8: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
column17: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

column8: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
column17: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO attacked the Lolere police post west of Torit town, along the Torit-Juba road, leaving two fire brigade members killed.
At least 15 people were confirmed killed over a land dispute at Kaljak area which lies on the border between South Sudan's Northern Liech and Ruweng States.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; UNSC; International Crisis Group
column17: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and Agwelek forces in northern Manyo county over 3-4 January. NDM claims to have killed more than 25 Agwelek forces while Agwelek claims to have killed 37 NDM, including two generals.
Seven people were confirmed killed and others wounded in an attack by gunmen along the Juba-Yei road near Jebel Kenyi in Loka.
five people were killed in separate incidents of cattle raiding in Northern Liech State at the beginning and the middle of the week
Government forces intercepted armed men when they attacked government positions in Torit. No casualties reported.

column9: Civilians (International); MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (South Sudan)
column17: Arrests: SPLA arrested six MSF humanitarian workers while on duty (two foreigners and four South Sudanese), suspecting them of smuggling guns to the opposition in Yei. Two staff were released on 27 January and four others on 31 March.
Unidentified men have kidnapped a Christian religious leader from his home in South Sudan's capital Juba

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Government claims that SPLA/M-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng. Both sides said more than 40 of their opponents died during Jan. 5 fighting.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO accuse government forces of attacking their base in Nasir town with tanks and helicopters. No people reportedly killed.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: One person was killed and six others injured when a soldier opened fire on a funeral rite in Yei. On the same day, another two people were killed in the Kimbi area of Yei by an unknown gunman.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Government claims that SPLA-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng.

""Four armed men broke in an INGO compound and were spotted by the site security guards. One of the guards was injured by a shot fired by one of the assailants. The security guard was taken to the hospital and then medically evacuated to another facility for further treatment.""

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: South Sudanese rebels loyal to former First Vice President Riek Machar announced that they captured Morobo County in Yei River State. The rebels claimed to kill 'several' government soldiers. Government forces denied the claim. Fighting escalated in the area.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Government claims that SPLA-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Five soldiers loyal to Lam Akol were captured during a battle by forces under the command of the SPLA-IO Sector One commander Lt. Gen. Johnson Olony at Kaka miliarity base

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Agwelek forces under the command of Lt. Gen. Johnson Olony and allied to SPLA-IO pursued and killed a commander Major General Yohanis Okiech Okic of Lam Akol's NDM rebel group, along with his 27 bodyguards.
""One national aid worker was taken into the bush and hacked to death during tribal violence. The attack was not the result of his employment as an aid worker.""

Non-violent activity: New party called the National Movement for Change (NMC) is formed from outside by the former governor of Western Equatoria. No mention if military campaign will be carried out or if will enter into agreement with active rebel groups of the country.
Unknown gunmen killed two people near Lokiliri county in Jubek state, as they were travelling from Magwi in Imatong State, to Juba.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Change to armed group: 250 government soldiers defected to the armed oppposition led by Riek Machar in Mayom county, Unity State, accusing the government of tribalism and nepotism.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Reported fighting between government and opposition near Yei town left 41 killed. Each side claimed victory and put the same number of fatalities on the other side.
Four people killed by suspected youth cattle raiders in Amolbut village, Lakes state, as they stole 60 heads of cattle and 30 goats from the area.

Suspected Murle tribesmen abducted a child at Tedo village in Pochalla North county. Around the same time, suspected Murle tribesmen also killed a member of Presbyterian Church near Kudbuudi village in Pochalla North county.
Murle tribesmen reportedly killed a local administrator in Neum village in Pochalla North county.

SPLA soldiers detained and shot at a group of 10 Kakwa youths in Yei, killing four of them instantly and injuring four others. Two were in a critical condition and arrangements were made for their medical evacuation on 14 January 2017. On the way to Yei airport, SPLA soldiers at a checkpoint stopped the vehicle in which the injured were travelling. They accused the accompanying doctor and driver of facilitating the escape of rebels, beat them, and briefly detained them at the military barracks. The doctor and driver were later released, and allowed to drive the men back to Yei hospital The two injured men later died of their injuries.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO in Unity in January left at least five civilians dead.

SPLA soldiers attacked a family of four at their home in Romogi, some 10km southeast of Wudu, Kajo-Keji county, on a Tuesday afternoon in January 2017. Three were killed while the mother escaped injured. In another incident in Romogi also in January, soldiers killed a disable man.
Unidentified gunmen abducted two children and wounded another in Bor East County.
SPLA soldiers abducted a man they suspected of being IO and killed him in January in Mere, Lire Payam in Kajo-Keji county.
Local officials in Buaw, Koch County, claimed that armed youth from Rubkona carried out cattle raids around between 16 December-1 March, resulting in civilian casualties.
At least 3 aid workers killed in January in South Sudan.
Intercommunal tensions in Rubkway, outside Leer, led to civilian casualties between 16 December-1 March.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: Cases of torture of detained people in Wudu in January were documented. At least three men died in detention as soldiers accused their father of belonging to the SPLM-IO.
Property destruction: Mathiang Anyoor militia, allied to the government, reportedly burned down at least 14 houses and the Catholic diocesan pastoral centre in Lutaya area, near Yei.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; National Courier; Eye Radio (South Sudan); UNSC
column17: Clashes between herders and suspected Murle tribesmen after an attack on Paluoch cattle camp in Duk Padiet by the tribesmen. At least 12 civilians were killed, while another 13 were injured and 2,000 cattle were stolen.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Change to armed group: Report that around 800 fighters from Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement defected to SPLA-IO led by Machar in Upper Nile early January. Lam Akol denied the report.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: Agreement: 11 SPLA-IO officials defected to Taban Deng Gai's faction to join the government's national dialogue.
Clashes between local residents and suspected Murle tribesmen left at least two people killed and another wounded in Pentin village in Pochalla South County.

Movement of forces: Government claims to have expelled all remaining Sudanese SPLM-N rebels from Wau and Raja in Bahr el Ghazal out of the country in line with a 2012 cooperation deal between the two countries.
Residents living in displaced camps under UN protection in Juba demonstrated peacefully in support of Donald Trump's swearing-in as the 45th president of the United States.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Road ambushed by men allegedly affiliated with a former SPLA coloner who had just defected to SPLA-IO left 2 SPLA soldiers killed and four injured near Mayom junction.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO reportedly repulsed a government attack on their positions in Khor Natabu area along the Bringi-Wau road in Wau State. No mention of fatalities. Authorities denied the clash.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; Gurtong Trust
column17: Suspected herders from Tonj state killed three civilians in or around Wath-lelo, Atido and Maleng areas of Jur River County between 20-21 January, after their cows were allegedly raided by rebels. Houses were burnt down and large populations displaced from the area.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Radio Tamazuj; UNSC; Catholic Radio Network
column17: Clashes between local farmers and Tonj pastoralists south of Wau town left at least two dead. During clashes between the Tonj and Wau communal militias in January, Tonj pastoralists were reportedly supported by government forces, while farmers in Wau were aided by SPLA-IO.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO forces reportedly regain control of Nordeng area in Nasir after SPLA removed them from the area the week prior. No mention of fatalities.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Protection Cluster; Radio Tamazuj; AP; Eye Radio (South Sudan); UNSC
column17: On 22 January, government and SPLA-IO forces clashed in Mondikolok, Kajo-Keji. On the side of the fighting, SPLA soldiers shot and killed seven civilians at a church service. There were also allegations of rape, physical mistreatment, robbery, theft, looting and abuse of power by the soldiers.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune
column17: SPLA-IO forces reportedly ambushed SPLA soldiers and supporting militias who were attacking and burning villages in Magwi county at Obbo Payam. At least 6 SPLA soldiers were killed. SPLA denied the claims.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: A clash between cattle keepers and SPLA-IO left at least six people killed in Wau state between 16-27 January, including two local community inhabitants, and many houses burnt down. SPLA-IO was said to have supported Wau farmers in clashes with Tonj herders in January, while Tonj herders were reportedly aided by government forces.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan News Agency; Catholic Radio Network; Sudan Tribune
column17: SPLA reportedly attacked SPLA-IO positions in and around Yei but were repulsed by SPLA-IO, leaving 18 killed. Civilians were reportedly killed in the fighting and displaced to border areas. In the course of the fighting, SPLA soldiers allegedly burnt down houses in Lutaya area, including a Pastoral Centre of the Catholic Diocese.

column16: UNSC; Protection Cluster; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); HRW
column17: On 22 January, government and SPLA-IO forces clashed in Mondikolok, Kajo-Keji. On the side of the fighting, SPLA soldiers shot and killed seven civilians at a church service. There were also allegations of rape, physical mistreatment, robbery, theft, looting and abuse of power by the soldiers.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO killed an SPLA soldier in Detang, Upper Nile, at some point between 22-25 January. This triggered further clashes in Malakal in the weeks that folllowed.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column7: FDP: Federal Democratic Party; SSAF: South Sudan Armed Forces
column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: Agreement: A senior general loyal to former First Vice President Machar defected to the SPLA-IO faction allied to incumbent First Vice President Taban Deng Gai with 175 of his soldiers in Panyijiar County in Unity state. The day after, 11 military officers from the opposition Federal Democratic Party/ South Sudan Armed Forces (FDP/SSAF) also defected to the SPLM-IO under Taban Deng Gai, while beginning of February, one of the SPLA-IO officials in Canada also announced his defection to Daban Deng's faction.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: HRW; UNSC; Protection Cluster; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 24 January, SPLA-IO forces attacked the Mere police station in Lire payam, Kajo-Keji, in retaliation for a clash the day before at Mondikolok and for the arrest of severeal people in the area accused of supporting them.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Fertit Lions: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Fertit Lions Faction)
column16: Sudan Tribune; CTSAMM; Small Arms Survey
column17: On January 24th, unknown gunmen killed a member of the Ceasefire and Transitional Security Arrangements Monitoring Mechanism (CTSAMM) after after unknown people convinced him to come out of a UN camp in Hai Jazeera near Wau town. Four men working inside the UN camp were later arrested over allegedly coordinating the killing. UPDATE: the killing has subsequently been attributed to SPLM-IO Fertit Tigers, and relates to an internal dispute.
Clashes between herders and local farmers as a farmer sought to prevent the herders' cattle to enter his lands in Pochalla North county in Jonglei left two herders killed.
Suspected herders from Tonj state stormed a cattle camp at night in Aliny village near Wau town, leaving three children killed and another three wounded.
Malakal town was shelled in the late morning; no casualties were reported. Unclear whether government or SPLA-IO shelled the town.

Alleged clashes between government forces and unknown gunmen in the week of 23 January after the gunmen ambushed a vehicle in Amaki along the Maridi-Rumbek road. No reported fatality. Authorities denied the claims.

column16: South Sudan News Agency; UNSC; Sudan Tribune
column17: Clashes between SPLA and rebels led by General Olonyi allied with Riek Machar in Detang, Lelo, Artakong and Burkiny areas near Malakal town, Upper Nile. The rebels reportedly repulsed government forces. At least five civilians were killed during the clashes.

column16: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency; UNSC
column17: Clashes between SPLA and rebels led by General Olonyi allied with Riek Machar in Detang, Lelo, Artakong and Burkiny areas near Malakal town, Upper Nile. The rebels reportedly repulsed government forces. At least five civilians were killed during the clashes.

column16: South Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; UNSC
column17: Clashes between SPLA and rebels led by General Olonyi allied with Riek Machar in Detang, Lelo, Artakong and Burkiny areas near Malakal town, Upper Nile. The rebels reportedly repulsed government forces. At least five civilians were killed during the clashes.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Suspected SPLA-IO rebels attacked the Kajo Keji police station, leaving two police officers killed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Change to armed group: A number of new and unnamed armed groups have reportedly emerged in Upper Nile after having recently broken away from SPLA-IO led by Riek Machar. Ceasefire monitors underlined that it hampered their capacity to reach some parts of the country.

column16: MSF; UNSC; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Owachi area in Upper Nile, near Malakal. One shell landed close to the MSF clinic in Malakal town.
Heavy fighting reported between government and Agwelek forces in Doleib Hill of Upper Nile at a point between 25 and 28 January. No mentioned fatality.

Suspected herders from Tonj state killed at least 11 civilians and burnt down houses in or around Wath-lelo, Atido and Maleng areas of Jur River County. Thousands of people were displaced to Wau town as a result of the tensions.

On the night of 27 January, the SPLA fired at least 32 shells from the East Bank towards Wau Shilluk using mortars and reportedly multi-barreled rocket launchers. At least five to seven civilian fatalities and 25 injured in Wau Shilluk. Shells also landed in Ogod, near Wau Shilluk, leaving at least two civilians dead and four injured.
Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Lelo, Warjwok and Detang of Upper Nile. No mention of fatalities.
Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Lelo, Warjwok and Detang of Upper Nile. No mention of fatalities.

Academic lecturers indefinitely suspended lessons at the University of Juba to protest the arrest and detention of two academics the day before for holding an alleged secret meeting after being suspended from the university for demanding the Vice Chancelor's removal in December.
Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Lelo, Warjwok and Detang of Upper Nile. No mention of fatalities.
Ambush by armed youth from Abiriu county on cattle raiders from Rumbek at Amolbut payam in Abiriu, Western Lake state, left two of the raiders dead.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on Sudanese refugees at Adjuong Thok camp in Pariang in Unity, killing at least one of them.

""Four trucks contracted by an INGO were attacked by gunmen on their way to Mayom in the morning. The driver was killed and two others were wounded and required medical attention at a clinic in Bentiu. One driver was unaccounted for after he fled the area. Further details on his whereabouts were not available during follow-up with the reporting agency.""

column9: Teachers (South Sudan); Students (South Sudan); Aid Workers (South Sudan); Christian Group (South Sudan)
column16: MSF; Radio Tamazuj; UN HRC; UNMISS; CTSAMM
column17: On 28 January, the SPLA ground offensive against SPLA-IO/Agwelek neared Wau Shilluk. They fired heavy shells as well as looted and burnt down property in the village, including schools, churches and humanitarian aid centres once they arrived. Some people reported to have died in the burning of huts. No opposition forces present.
Gunmen opened fire on a car along the Juba-Nimule road, leaving at least three people killed and several others wounded.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Sporadic clashes between government and SPLA-IO continued around Doleib Hill.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Gabat (Manyo county) and Khor (Melut county) areas of Upper Nile on 30 January. Opposition claimed to have captured the two areas, which SPLA denied. No reported fatalities.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; IOM; UNOCHA
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Kuek (melut county), Abu Khadra and Mamur areas of Renk, Upper Nile, around 30 January. In Kuek, SPLA-IO claimed that SPLA was supported by Sudanese rebels from JEM and SPLM-N. Significant displacement reported from the area, with some humanitarian organisations shutting down operations due to insecurity.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Gabat (Manyo county) and Khor (Melut county) areas of Upper Nile on 30 January. Opposition claimed to have captured the two areas, which SPLA denied. No reported fatalities.

Looting: Unknown gunmen attacked two humanitarian convoys between 29-31 January in Bentiu, Unity state, raising concerns about the safety of humanitarian convoys that take advantage of the dry season to preposition stocks in remote regions.

Reports that Misseriya tribesmen have been attacking Dinka Malual farmers, fishermen and hunters over January-February in Aweil East, leaving at least four people killed in an attack on the farm of Yel Deng Nguel. Other ambushes have forced people to stop hunting and fishing in the area.
SPLA allegedly attacked civilian houses in Yei town over 30-31 January, leaving at least three civilians killed, three others wounded and property looted.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On January 30th, two individuals were killed by NSS agents at the security complex in Luri (Central Equatoria). The individuals had been living in exile in Nairobi, where they had been abducted several days before and transferred to the 'Blue House' in Juba on Jan 27th. There has been widespread condemnation of the NSS and South Sudanese authorities following the release of this information on April 30th 2019; the government has denied being responsible for the events, and suggested that enquiries be directed to the Kenyan government.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and suspected SPLA-IO forces in Wau town at night left at least three killed and two wounded.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Kuek (melut county), Abu Khadra and Mamur areas of Renk, Upper Nile, around 30 January. In Kuek, SPLA-IO claimed that SPLA was supported by Sudanese rebels from JEM and SPLM-N. Significant displacement reported from the area, with some humanitarian organisations shutting down operations due to insecurity.
SPLA allegedly attacked civilian houses in Yei town over 30-31 January, leaving at least three civilians killed, three others wounded and property looted.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces continued from 31 January-1 February in Wadakona area in Upper Nile. Opposition fighters were allegedly repulsed by government forces. SPLA-IO denied the clashes in Wadakona. No reported fatality.
SPLA spokesman claims that SPLA bombarded SPLA-IO positions in Jonglei and Unity on the week of 27 January. No reported fatality.

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: Unknown gunmen shot and killed a Presidential Guard soldier and driver for President Kiir's wife while he was off duty in Wau town. Police later arrested two over the attack.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes between government and opposition forces continued from 31 January-1 February in Wadakona area in Upper Nile. Opposition fighters were allegedly repulsed by government forces. SPLA-IO denied the clashes in Wadakona. No reported fatality.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping six bombs in Wau Shilluk in Upper Nile. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.
SPLA spokesman claims that SPLA bombarded SPLA-IO positions in Jonglei and Unity on the week of 27 January. No reported fatality.

column6: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Dinka Bor cattle keepers, supported by SPLA, allegedly attacked armed opposition elements in Kajo Keji and Nyepo counties end January/early February. No reported fatality.

Toposa militiamen allegedly supported by SPLA forces attacked settlements of Kenyan pastoralists who had crossed the border from Turkana in search of water and pasture for their cattle, forcing them back to Turkana. No reported fatality.
Unknown gunmen ambushed two people on the road in Bar Mayen county, Aweil state, around 1 February, leaving one of them killed. Police later arrested four in connection with the killing.
Reports of shelling of Wau Shilluk on 1-2 February causing civilian casualties. SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping six bombs on Wau Shilluk. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Mustaqbal, Gabat near Wadakona and Dentoang on 2 February. Many fatalities reported. SPLA denied receiving support from Sudanese rebels. SPLA-IO claimed to have captured nine government soldiers and destroyed four military vehicles.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: AP; Xinhua; Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency
column17: Change to armed group: An SPLA Colonel defects to SPLA-IO denouncing institutionalized tribalism, fascism and political militarism. A week later, one of the most senior SPLA Generals from Equatoria resigned denouncing ethnic bias and ""unacceptable cycles of violence"" in the country, while SPLA announced that about 151 SPLA-IO rebels defected from Akobo in Jonglei.
Reports of shelling of Wau Shilluk on 1-2 February causing civilian casualties. SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping six bombs on Wau Shilluk. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Mustaqbal, Gabat near Wadakona and Dentoang on 2 February. Many fatalities reported. SPLA denied receiving support from Sudanese rebels. SPLA-IO claimed to have captured nine government soldiers and destroyed four military vehicles.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Mustaqbal, Gabat near Wadakona and Dentoang on 2 February. Many fatalities reported. SPLA denied receiving support from Sudanese rebels. SPLA-IO claimed to have captured nine government soldiers and destroyed four military vehicles.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping more than nine bombs in rebel-held territories around Kaka in Upper Nile. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Renewed clashes between government and opposition forces in Wau Shilluk, Upper Nile. The town was reportedly deserted. By the 4th, government forces said they were in control of the town.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Dentoang for the second day. Government forces were repulsed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes reported between government and opposition forces in Gabat near Wadakona on 3 February. Government forces were repulsed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Clashes reported between opposition forces and the ""Mathiang Anyoor militia"" of Bahr el Ghazal, loyal to the government, at Ombasi in Yei River County, left 32 government militiamen killed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Renewed clashes between government and opposition forces in Wau Shilluk, Upper Nile. The town was reportedly deserted. By the 4th, government forces said they were in control of the town.
Suspected Murle militiamen ambushed a group of four women in Baidit in Jonglei's Bor South, leaving two killed and the two others injured.

Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Kuek (Melut county) over 5-6 February. Government forces claimed to have regained the area from the rebels, which SPLA-IO denied.

""An INGO contracted driver was kidnapped in the Ajira area in Kajo Keji. Approximately eight men approached the vehicle when it was stopped due to a flat tire. It was a private vehicle but clearly marked with the INGO's flag. Other staff members were in the vehicle as well during the attack but they were released in the Bori area with their valuables intact. The vehicle and the driver were still missing when this was reported and their whereabouts were not able to be confirmed upon verification a year later.""

Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Kuek (Melut county) over 5-6 February. Government forces claimed to have regained the area from the rebels, which SPLA-IO denied.
Unknown gunmen described as ""rebels"" reportedly fired mortar rounds on Torit town. No casualties.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: Unknown gunmen shot and killed a prison warder off duty at his home in Yambio. Police later arrested six in connection with the attack.
Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Detang over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this areas from the rebels.

The Ngop River County Commissioner's bodyguard allegedly shot and killed a pastoralist youth leader in Eastern Lakes state as ordered by the Commissionner over unclear circumstances. Clashes erupted the following day.
Suspected Murle militiamen ambushed a group of women collecting firewood at Panwell in Jonglei's Bor South, leaving two killed and others injured.
Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Detang over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this areas from the rebels.
Clashes between youth pastoralists and soldiers in Mapuordit payam in Yirol west county, Lakes state following the killing of one of their leaders, left two people killed.
Looting: Suspected cattle raiders from Boma allegedly attacked a cattle camp in Duk County of Jonglei. No casualty.
A trader was killed in Lui town in Mundri. Some accused SPLA. SPLA denounced as dangerous propaganda.

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North)
column16: UNMISS; Radio Tamazuj; UNSC; South Sudan News Agency
column17: Government soldiers backed by Sudanese rebels (from SPLM-N and JEM) attacked Agwelek forces' positions at Owachi near Malakal but were repulsed by the rebels. ""Significant"" casualties reported by UN on both sides - SPLA-IO claiming to have killed more than 98 government soldiers, while SPLA denied the clashes.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
