On October 13th, a group of armed men attacked a passenger vehicle in the area of Aluakluak (Lakes state) as it was travelling towards Rumbek. Two civilians were killed and one was wounded in the attack (all of whom were believed to be University students).

On October 13th, gunmen boarded a commercial boat travelling to Bor, either at Shambe or in the area Gedakwet (different locations provided in different sources. Coordinates for Shambe, Lakes State, have been used). The attackers looted up to 7 million SSP from the passengers, although nobody was reported injured in the incident. As of Oct 18th four people in total had been apprehended (along with at least some of the stolen money), two of whom were reported to be soldiers.
On October 13th, students numbering in their hundreds bloackaded roads in Rumbek (Lakes state) in protest against the killing of two University students earlier that day.

On October 13th, three children were abducted by an unknown group (alleged to be herders) at Chalara village (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Lokiliri used). Authorities have begun a search for the missing children.

On October 14th, an intra-group clash between guards of the FVP Deng Gai left a soldier killed in the Tongping nieghbourhood of Juba (Central Equatoria). The FVP was not in the residence at the time. The violence was not related to the FVP himself.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 14th, NAS and SPLM-IO forces clashed in Logo (Central Equatoria). The IO accused NAS forces of assaulting their positions, and of killing 12 ""worshippers"" at their base. The NAS denied attacking the IO forces.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: From October 3rd to October 14th, clashes between the SPLA and SPLM-IO took place in various locations in the vicinity of Wau (Western Bahr el Ghazal). Fighting was reported to have taken place in the villages of Bagari (approximate coordinates used), Ngisa, Tado, and Ngoku. An SPLM-IO spokesman said that military and civilian lives had been lost in the violence (10 fatalities spread over 12 battle events), whilst an SPLM-IO commander and his wife were abducted. Both sides accuse the other of being behind the hostilities.

On October 14th, an armed group - allegedly cattle raiders from Aluakluak - attacked and killed three people at an unspecified location in Paloc county (Lakes state, approximate coordinates for Pagan used based on humanitarian source).
On October 14th, three civilians were reportedly killed in attack in Aduel (Lakes state). There are no further details, including information on the attackers.
On October 14th, a man riding a motorbike was shot dead at an unspecified location on the road between Yirol and Aluakluak (coordinates for Aluaklauk, Lakes state, used).

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: At an unspecified time between mid-September to late December, NAS forces attacked SPLM-IO forces at Minyori and Maukaya payams (both Central Equatoria, used at geoprec2) on at least one occasion. Two events coded in October and November at time prec3.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 15th and 16th, SPLM-IO and NAS forces continued to clash in Minori (Central Equatoria). 800 civilians are reported to have been displaced in the violence.

In October, 7 people were killed and a child wounded in attacks at an unspecified location in Tonj East county. The violence followed a dispute after a young man murdered a woman who refused to marry him.

Between September and December 2018, rebels attacked multiple villages across Central Equatoria at unspecified areas in Kenyi, Lasu, Lobonok and Mugwo payams (all at prec2), and two other unspecified locations. Seven events coded at time prec3 across different months, with five assigned to the NAS at confirmed areas of activity, and two to the SPLM-IO at unconfirmed locations (coordinates for Yei and Liggi used at geoprec2). 50 fatalities spread across the seven events.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between September and December 2018, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked two unspecified villages in Central Equatoria, killing thirteen people. Government forces were also linked to 26 cases of rape and 3 cases of forced nudity in and around Yei, though the source does not specify how many of these rapes occurred in the context of attacks on villages. Three events coded at time prec3 using Yei at geoprec2, with fatalities spread across events.

Between September and December 2018, rebels abducted 74 civilians across nine events in various locations in Central Equatoria (including Alero, Logo, Lasu, and Yembe (approx coordinates from humanitarian map used for Yembe at prec2), and several unspecified locations along the Yei-Kaya road. Nine events recorded (six with NAS as actor1, three with SPLM-IO as actor1) all at time prec3, with eight events using specific locations, and one event using Yei at geoprec3.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between September and December 2018, government forces (comprising SSPDF and NSS units) attacked rebel areas in Central Equatoria, including Limbe, Kopera, and Goli (no coordinates found, Yei used at prec2). Three events coded (two involving NAS, and one SPLM-IO) at time prec3. Three fatalities coded for each event, on the assumption that fatalities occurred.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: During the month of October, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped five women in Lang (Unity state).

During the month of October, a police officer was killed by local youth on the outskirts of Bor town (Jonglei state). The killing was reportedly a revenge attack. Note: as there is no mention of a firefight- assumed the officer was off-duty.
During the month of October, NAS rebels were reported to have abducted ""dozens"" of civilians in and around Yei (Central Equatoria).

column7: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF or SPLM-IO Taban Deng, given their presence in the area) raped and beat women in Tharkoat (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Three events at time precision 3 have been coded, with SSPDF and Taban Deng's forces alternating as actor1 and assoc actor 1

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be SSPDF given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped and beat women in Darasalam (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Two events at time precision 3 have been coded, to avoid overlap with MSF source covering attacks in late November.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF, SPLM-IO, or SPLM-IO Taban Deng) raped and beat women in Padai (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Two events at time precision 3 have been coded, to avoid overlap with MSF source covering attacks in late November.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be SPLM-IO given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped and beat women in Thowmangor (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Two events at time precision 3 have been coded, to avoid overlap with MSF source covering attacks in late November.
On October 16th, gunmen shot and killed an Eritrean trader in Kapoeta (Eastern Equatoria) in his place of business. Two suspects have been arrested.

""One local NGO staff member in Kapoeta was shot in the abdomen when armed assailants broke into the organization's compound. The staff member was taken to the hospital, but there is no further information about his prognosis. The motive for the attack is unknown at this time.""

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 15th and 16th, SPLM-IO and NAS forces continued to clash in Minori (Central Equatoria). 800 civilians are reported to have been displaced in the violence.

column8: SSLM/A: South Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Splinter Faction)
column17: On October 16th, General Jacob Nyier (a commander in Bapiny Monytuil's SSLM/A rebellion) announced that he had taken control of the rebel group, with the support of unspecified members of the rebellion. Bapiny Monytuil denounced the move, and says he remains as leader of the group.

column8: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On October 16th, security guards employed by Warrior Security (recently acquired by Insight) protested in Juba, over unpaid benefits, a desire for increased wages, and the terms of the new contracts soon to be introduced as a result of the takeover. The guards locked the gates to the UNMISS compound in Juba.

""One male national INGO staff member was taken by an opposition group after a dispute regarding the INGO project's drilling equipment in Jiech, Jonglei state. The staff member was released after 2 weeks, but had injuries to various parts of his body.""
On October 17th, a Kenyan working for a local South Sudanese NGO was shot and wounded by unknown attackers in Kapoeta (Eastern Equatoria).
On October 21st, armed raiders believed to have come from Panyijiar county attacked an unspecified location in Adior county (Lakes state). They abducted three children, and stole hundreds of cattle.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before October 22nd, the FDP accused the SPLM-IO of seizing their positions in Kotker (Upper Nile). There were no reports of casualties, though the FDP said two of their commanders were captured. The SPLM-IO denied that such an attack took place (claiming that the FDP do not have forces in the area), though acknowledged that they had arrested an individual for engaging in ""suspicious activities"" in Nasir.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before Oct 23rd, SPLM-IO and NAS rebels clashed near Kenyira market in Mugwo payam (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Yari used at precision 2).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On Oct 23rd, SPLM-IO rebels attacked Kenyira market in Mugwo payam (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Yari used at precision 2), killing seven civilians and raping two women.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before October 24th, government attacked SPLM-IO positions in Bazia county (Western Bahr el Ghazal), according to the IO spokesman. There was no comment from the government.

On or before October 24th, three civilians were abducted in the Ngovendeko area in Wau, whilst houses were looted and torched. The attack came amidst clashes between the government and SPLA-IO forces.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before October 24th, government forces attacked SPLM-IO positions in Bagari county (Western Bahr el Ghazal), according to the IO spokesman. There was no comment from the government.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 24h, government SSPDF forces attacked SPLM-IO positions at Limuro (Central Equatoria), according to the IO. Civilians fled to Uganda. The government has not commented.
""An NGO national staff member was shot dead in the line of duty in what was a revenge killing in Fangak, Jonglei.""

column6: Western Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Western Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: During the week beginning October 22nd, two Western Jikany Nuer sub-clans clashed at an unspecified location in Guit county (Unity state). Two people were killed in the attack, one of whom was the deputy chief of the one of the sub-clans.

""One male security guard reportedly sustained injuries that required medical attention after a group of three males assaulted him at the PoC gate in Malakal. A UN contractor was also involved in the assault, but did not sustain injuries .""

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 25th, the government released five prisoners being held in the NSS detention facility known as the Blue House on the outskirts of Juba (Central Equatoria). The released included Marko Lokidor Lochapio, an SPLM-IO governor who had reportedly been abducted whilst in Kenya. The move follows the release of 24 prisoners on October 19th, though several high-profile detainees remain in NSS custody.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 26th, government SSPDF forces attacked SPLM-IO positions at Kendiri (Central Equatoria), according to the IO. The government has not responded to the claim.

On or around October 26th, three men gang-raped a 13 year-old girl as she gathered firewood with her younger sister, on the outskirts of Wau near the UNMISS base (Western Bahr el Ghazal). Police have arrested the suspects.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: On October 27th, raiders described as ""Gelweng"" by a state-level minister (recorded here as a Dinka Ethnic Militia) attacked the village of Apero in Abiriu county (Lakes state), resulting in fighting with police. Four people died during the attack, including a policeman, and a further fifteen were injured (some reports say five killed, and 17 or 20 injured). The attackers also stole a large amount of cattle.
On October 27th, an unidentified group attacked a commercial vehicle travelling on the Juba-Bor road (coordinates for Bor, Joglei state, used). A student was wounded in the attack.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Wildlife Police
column17: On October 28th, two attackers shot and killed a Wildlife officer (coded here as Police Forces of South Sudan) whilst he was on-duty in the Tambura East area (coordinates for Tambura, Western Equatoria, used). Two suspects have been arrested.

column9: Aid Workers (South Sudan); Civilians (International); Aid Workers (International)
column17: ""An INGO convoy was attacked traveling on the Juba-Lainya road by several armed men at Kwerjik. One INGO national staff member was killed and ten other staff members were abducted. Seventeen staff members that were part of the convoy were able to flee and reach the South Sudan People’s Defence Force (SSPDF) camp. All the abducted staff members were later released.""

On October 29th, around 200 students from the at Dr John Garang Memorial University of Science and Technology gathered in Bor (Jonglei state) to protest against insecurity on the Juba-Bor road, following the wounding of a student two days prior.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, government forces (comprising SSPDF and NSS units) attacked rebel areas in Central Equatoria, including Limbe, Kopera, and Goli (no coordinates found, Yei used at prec2). Three events coded (two involving NAS, and one SPLM-IO) at time prec3. Three fatalities coded for each event, on the assumption that fatalities occurred.

Between September and December 2018, rebels attacked multiple villages across Central Equatoria at unspecified areas in Kenyi, Lasu, Lobonok and Mugwo payams (all at prec2), and two other unspecified locations. Seven events coded at time prec3 across different months, with five assigned to the NAS at confirmed areas of activity, and two to the SPLM-IO at unconfirmed locations (coordinates for Yei and Liggi used at geoprec2). 50 fatalities spread across the seven events.

Between September and December 2018, rebels abducted 74 civilians across nine events in various locations in Central Equatoria (including Alero, Logo, Lasu, and Yembe (approx coordinates from humanitarian map used for Yembe at prec2), and several unspecified locations along the Yei-Kaya road. Nine events recorded (six with NAS as actor1, three with SPLM-IO as actor1) all at time prec3, with eight events using specific locations, and one event using Yei at geoprec3.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, rebel forces were reported to have conducted 10 targeted killings of civilians at unspecified locations in Central Equatoria state, typically at road blocks or checkpoints. Two events coded (one with SPLM-IO as actor1, another with NAS as actor 1) at time precision 3 with five fatalities apiece. Yei used at geoprec3.

Between September and December 2018, rebel forces were reported to have conducted 10 targeted killings of civilians at unspecified locations in Central Equatoria state, typically at road blocks or checkpoints. Two events coded (one with SPLM-IO as actor1, another with NAS as actor 1) at time precision 3 with five fatalities for each event . Yei used at geoprec2 for one event, and Liggi at geoprec2 for the other.

On October 30th, raiders (suspected of being Murle youth) attacked Poktap (Jonglei). A lengthy battle took place between local youth and the raiders between 10 and 15kms from the town itself, in which five local youths and two raiders were killed, and fifteen injured. According to the county commissioner, 6,000 cattle were stolen, all of which were recovered.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 31st, Dr Riek Machar returned to Juba to participate in the peace celebrations. The event - which was attended by Presidents Omar el-Bashir and Yoweri Museveni - took place amidst heavy security, though no security incidents were reported. Two days prior to this, the SSPDF rejected the proposed doubling of the UN Regional Protection Force.

""An INGO security guard was attacked in Leer while he was off-duty and standing behind the INGO's compound. He sustained serious injuries and was taken to a medical facility for treatment. The suspects escaped.""

On October 31st, raiders (suspected to belong to the Murle ethnic group) attacked the cattle camp of Akot in the area of Jalle payam (Jonglei). The county commissioner for Bor North said the raiders killed 9 people (including three women and a young child), whilst 7 were injured. Many cattle were also reported to be stolen, and the cattle camp was destroyed. Update: A subsequent news report revised the death toll updwards to 10, and noted that nearly 780 families have been displaced by the attack.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On November 2nd, two prominent SPLM-IO detainees (James Gatdet Dak, former IO spokesman, and William Endley, a South African national and military consultant to the IO) were released in Juba, following their Presidential pardon two days earlier. Both had been sentenced to death.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: On November 2nd, eight women and girls were beaten by a group of men in military and civilian attire (likely to be either regular SSPDF or Taban Deng's forces given their presence in the area, who are coded as actor1 and assoc actor1 respectively) in Tharkoat (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN report used at prec2).
On November 2nd, local youth opened fire on indiviudals to prevent an inter-family crime in Tirangore village (Eastern Equatoria). Three injured and the perpetrators escaped.

""An NGO vehicle was ambushed by armed men while travelling from Koch at the Nimni road junction. Two people were hurt in the attack, one was an NGO staff member. They were admitted to the hospital in Bentiu to have their gunshot wounds treated.""

On November 5th, violence between two local groups took place at an unspecified location in Thiet county (Warrap state). The source is vague on details, but the dispute appears to involve relatives of a couple engaged to one another. One group of relatives beat a member of the other to death with sticks in a local police station (though police are not mentioned as a participating actor by the source), whilst the other set of relatives burned down three dwellings belonging to the other in retaliation.
On November 6th, a group of ""unknown gunmen"" first raped and then killed a pregnant lady in Wau (Western Bahr el Ghazal).

On November 9th, a local chief and his son were shot dead whilst they were travelling to Akot for a peace conference (coordinates for Akot, Lakes state, used). The county commissioner alleged the attackers came from the Aluak-Luak area of Lakes. The peace conference was cancelled as a result of the killing.

On November 10th, two police officers were killed by an armed youth group in Bor (Jonglei state), coded here as two separate events occurring on the same day. After the first police officer was killed in Bor town, a youth who was arrested by the police escaped the police station in Bor, and his associates then ambushed and killed another police officer who was pursuing the escapee (wounding an additional police officer and two soldiers), at an area called Cuei-nyok located between Koch and Bor (coordinates for Bor used). By November 12th, three suspects had been arrested in connection with the ambush.

On November 10th, two police officers were killed by an armed youth group in Bor (Jonglei state), coded here as two separate events occurring on the same day. After the first police officer was killed in Bor town, a youth who was arrested by the police escaped the police station in Bor, and his associates then ambushed and killed another police officer who was pursuing the escapee (wounding an additional police officer and two soldiers), at an area called Cuei-nyok located between Koch and Bor (coordinates for Bor used). By November 12th, three suspects had been arrested in connection with the ambush.

On or before November 11th, a number of youths protested in Renk (Upper Nile), against the appointment of a new mayor who hailed from outside of the Renk area. Between 12 and 22 youth were arrested by police for allegedly unruly behaviour (the numbers vary between the two sources, note that there is no mention of demonstrator activity which could qualify as rioting).
On November 11th, a police officer shot dead two civilians at a checkpoint in Juba (Central Equatoria). The motive for the shooting is unclear, and the officer was immediately arrested.

On November 13th, unidentified gunmen shot dead a 16 year-old school girl in Torit (Eastern Equatoria). According to the source, the attackers forced the victim to produce a weapon belonging to her father, which they used to shoot her with. One source mentions that the attackers were in military uniform.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: At an unspecified time between mid-September to late December, NAS forces attacked SPLM-IO forces at Minyori and Maukaya payams (both Central Equatoria, used at geoprec2) on at least one occasion. Two events coded- one in October and November at time prec3.

column6: Apuk-Padoch Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Apuk-Padoch Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On November 15th, an armed clash erupted within the Apuk Padoch Dinka clan in an unspecified part of Tonj state. 10 people were killed and seven wounded. Security forces arrested 25 suspects (the source reports the fight was sparked by a young girl being impregnated, leading to reprisal violence against the father's family).

Between September and December 2018, rebels attacked multiple villages across Central Equatoria at unspecified areas in Kenyi, Lasu, Lobonok and Mugwo payams (all at prec2), and two other unspecified locations. Seven events coded at time prec3 across different months, with five assigned to the NAS at confirmed areas of activity, and two to the SPLM-IO at unconfirmed locations (coordinates for Yei and Liggi used at geoprec2). 50 fatalities spread across the seven events.

Between September and December 2018, rebels abducted 74 civilians across nine events in various locations in Central Equatoria (including Alero, Logo, Lasu, and Yembe (approx coordinates from humanitarian map used for Yembe at prec2), and several unspecified locations along the Yei-Kaya road. Nine events recorded (six with NAS as actor1, three with SPLM-IO as actor1) all at time prec3, with eight events using specific locations, and one event using Yei at geoprec3.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between September and December 2018, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked two unspecified villages in Central Equatoria, killing thirteen people. Government forces were also linked to 26 cases of rape and 3 cases of forced nudity in and around Yei, though the source does not specify how many of these rapes occurred in the context of attacks on villages. Three events coded at time prec3 using Yei at geoprec2, with fatalities spread across events.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: During the month of November, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped five women in Lang (Unity state).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: During the month of November, SPLM-IO rebels tortured an elderly farmer as he travelled to Kurudja (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Kujugale used at precision), cutting off his ears, before killing him with an axe.
During the month of November, four SSPDF soldiers raped a woman at an unspecified location near Yei (Central Equatoria). There is no further information.

On November 15th, a Catholic priest from Kenya was killed by unknown gunmen at the Jesuit compound he worked in, in Cueibet town (Lakes state). Three men have been arrested in connection with his death, who admit to killing the priest, though one suspect is still at large. The motive is not clear.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF or SPLM-IO Taban Deng, given their presence in the area) raped and beat women in Tharkoat (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Three events at time precision 3 have been coded, with SSPDF and Taban Deng's forces alternating as actor1 and assoc actor 1

At an unspecified time in November, three of Governor David Yau Yau's bodyguards were killed by an armed group (coded as a Murle militia), in or near Lukkuangole (Jonglei state). Yau Yau was reportedly attempting to secure the return of cattle stolen from western Jonglei, and three abducted children believed to have been taken from Lafon (Eastern Equatoria) at an unspecified time. Both the children and cattle were reclaimed.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On November 16th, NAS forces accused the SPLM-IO as well as government forces of launching a joint attack on NAS positions in the area of Lobonok (Central Equatoria). SPLM-IO insisted that the incident was related to a re-defection of two NAS commanders back to the SPLM-IO, which sparked an attack against the defecting forces by the NAS.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On November 16th, the SPLM-IO (responding to NAS allegations of a joint attack by IO and government forces against NAS rebels earlier that same day near Lobonok) claimed that NAS forces from Lainya sent to reinforce NAS soldiers in Lobonok were intercepted by forces (re)defecting from the NAS to the SPLM-IO.
On November 17th, unknown gunmen killed a police officer in Wau (Western Bahr el Ghazal). The state security advisor for the (disputed) Wau state claimed the attackers were criminals.

On November 17th, suspected raiders from Pibor attacked a cattle camp in the vicinity of Wanglei (Jonglei state), resulting in one death and one injury (note that the source does not specify whether an exchange of fire took place) and stolen cattle.

column9: Women (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On November 17th, two women were tied to a tree and raped by two armed men (likely SSPDF, given their presence in the area) near Khalibalek close to Bentiu (Unity state, coordinates used at prec2).

On or around November 18th, armed youth attacked a passenger vehicle on the road between Aluakluak Gadiem and Aluakluak Jadiet (coordinates for Aluakluak, Lakes state, used). Three women were raped by the attackers, and then robbed.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

On November 20th, disabled soldiers protested in Juba (Central Equatoria) over the non-payment of medical allowences. The Minister of the Interior acknowledged the issue, and pledged that the government would resolve the matter.

On November 20th, a police officer was shot dead by an unidentified group in Ngap county (coordinates for Cueibet, Lakes state, used). The attackers were suspected of coming from a neighbouring state, and were in the process of raiding cattle. The officer died as he was protecting a civilian from the raiders.

""One national NGO contracted driver was heading home (most likely on foot) when he was attacked by a criminal gang that brandished machetes. This was a violent assault which led to the hospitalization of the driver. The incident occurred in the Hai Loklili residential area, close to Jebek Kujur in Central Equatoria. The motive for the attack is unknown.""

column9: Lou Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (South Sudan)
column17: On 20 November 2018, suspected Murle militiamen killed eight members of the Lou Nuer community (coded here as civilians) escorting WFP barges in the area of Lokurmach or Lokomai (approximates coordinates for Lokurmach, Jonglei state). The SPLM-IO authorities of the disputed Bieh state accused a Murle militia acting at the behest of the government-controlled Boma state of orchestrating the attack.

column8: Apuk-Padoch Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On November 20, in Tonj (Tonj South, Warrap), security authorities arrested 25 suspects believed to have been involved in inter-clan conflicts last week leading to the deaths of 10 people.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: On November 21st, three men from an unspecified armed group (likely to be SPLM-IO given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped a pregnant woman in Thaliel (Unity state).

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

On November 22nd, IDPs at the UNMISS base in Jebel on the outskirts of Juba (Central Equatoria) demonstrated against a cut in food rations, and the alleged lack of food rations for the past three months.

On November 22nd, an unidentified armed group fired at a commercial vehicle travelling along the Juba-Bor road, at the area of Panpitiak. Two people were wounded in the gunfire, and three children were abducted.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

On Nov 23rd, SSPDF soldiers killed a civilian (whom they suspected of being an informant for the NAS rebellion) at an unspecified location in Wonduruba county (Central Equatoria). As a retalliatory attack was reported to been enacted the following month by NAS forces, NAS has been coded as assoc actor 2, on the understanding that the victim may well have been an informant.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

On November 24th, a group of suspected local youth armed with sticks and machetes killed a soldier who intervened to protect a girl they came to attack. Eight suspects (four men, and four women) have been arrested in connection with the incident.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: On November 25th, an unspecified armed group (likely to be SPLM-IO forces given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped four young women and girls in the area of Nhialdiu (Unity state).

On November 25th, an unknown group locked the doors to a house belonging to a local headteacher with ten children in it, and then set fire to the structure. The event occurred in Torit (Eastern Equatoria), and comes amidst a spate of incidents of arson this year. No casualties. A police spokesman blamed revellers from local nightclubs.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

At an unspecified date (likely towards the end of November), SSPDF soldiers attacked a student in Bor (Jonglei state) as he was returning home in the early evening. This comes amidst a series of complaints against the behaviour of soldiers towards civilians in the city.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.

On November 28th, SSPDF soldiers were ambushed by suspected Murle militia in the area of Kubal (note that Kubal is the name of a river; coordinates for Gumuruk, Jonglei state, used), killing three SSPDF troops. The soldiers had been pursuing cattle raiders who had been active in western Jonglei, and had recovered cattle, only to have the cattle stolen again by the armed youth who ambushed the soldiers.

Between November 19th and 29th, 125 women of ages ranging between 10 to over 65 were reported to have been victims of sexual violence, beatings and robberies in Rubkona county (Unity state), according to a statement issued by MSF, who also noted that this rapid increase in the volume of cases was unprecedented in South Sudan. The source does not specify who was behind the attacks. Coded as one VAC event each day.
On or before November 29th, a teacher was murdered in Bor (Jonglei state). The attacker(s) are unknown.

On November 29th, unknown gunmen attacked a house in Torit (Eastern Equatoria), spraying the house with bullets, and killing an eight-year old girl in the process. The attackers then abducted the father of the victim.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, rebels attacked multiple villages across Central Equatoria at unspecified areas in Kenyi, Lasu, Lobonok and Mugwo payams (all at prec2), and two other unspecified locations. Seven events coded at time prec3 across different months, with five assigned to the NAS at confirmed areas of activity, and two to the SPLM-IO at unconfirmed locations (coordinates for Yei and Liggi used at geoprec2). 50 fatalities spread across the seven events.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, rebels abducted 74 civilians across nine events in various locations in Central Equatoria (including Alero, Logo, Lasu, and Yembe (approx coordinates from humanitarian map used for Yembe at prec2), and several unspecified locations along the Yei-Kaya road. Nine events recorded (six with NAS as actor1, three with SPLM-IO as actor1) all at time prec3, with eight events using specific locations, and one event using Yei at geoprec3.

column8: SSUA-Gadet: Southern Sudan United Army (IO Faction)
column17: On November 30th, Peter Gadet's SSUM/A announced that Gadet had been elected as leader of the SSOA (which signed the recent peace agreement with the government and SPLM-IO), replacing Gabriel Changson as interim leader.One member of the SSOA disputed Gadet's victory, insisting that unanimity was required, and claimed a plot to destroy the SSOA was being pursued.

On December 1st and/or December 2nd, two armed Nyang Dinka sub-clans (the Kwac-thiin and Kwac-diit ) clashed at Kwacdiit (coordinates for Yirol, Lakes state, used), leaving four dead and seventeen wounded. The dispute appears to centre upon a grazing area.

On December 4th, two Bul Nuer clans (the Jak, and Chien-Thii) clashed at Kech near Bentiu, resulting in 14 fatalities. The fight was allegedly sparked by the rape of a Jak clan woman (coded in a separate event). According to the source, nine members of the Chien-Thii clan (including one woman) were killed, and five members of the Jak clan lost their lives.
On December 4th, members of a Bul Nuer clan (Chien-Thii) raped a woman from another Bul Nuer clan (the Jak) at Kech near Bentiu, sparking clashes between the two groups (coded in a separate event).
In early December, NAS rebels abducted fifteen civilians at an unspecified location on the road between Yei and Lasu (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Yei used at precision 2).
In early December, NAS rebels abducted six civilians at an unspecified location on the road between Yei and Kaya (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Yei used at precision 2).

column9: Women (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: During early December, two armed men (likely SSPDF, given their presence in the area) killed a 50 year-old woman and raped her daughter, near Koch (Unity state).
On December 6th, an unknown group attacked a passenger vehicle in the area of Ajak Kuac (Warrap state), killing two and seriously wounding seven others. There are no further details.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 7 December 2018, a Malawian businessman was extradited to Juba after being arrested in Rwanda by NSS personnel whilst transiting in Rwanda, after he was accused of owing $350,000 to a local company. The man was taken to various detention sites in Juba until his eventual release in March 2020, when he was frequently tortured, and forced to perform laborious tasks for his captors. The victim has since returned to Malawi.

On December 8th, cattle raiders shot dead a policeman guarding cattle, and wounded a trader. The event occurred at an unspecified location along the Mapel-Rumbek road (coordinates for Rumbek, Lakes state, used. Note that the source describes the event as taking place in the disputed Western Lakes state, meaning the attack would have occurred closer to Rumbek than to the towns of Tonj or Mapel, which are in the disputed Tonj state).

Prior to December 9th, local officials in the disputed Amadi state (formerly Western Equatoria) claimed the NAS forces were forcibly recruiting youth in the Jambo and Kategiri areas of the state (coordinates for Jambo, Western Equatoria, used). The Deputy Governor of Amadi state also claimed that NAS forces were looting and ""causing insecurity"" in the areas they were based.

On December 9th, a militia from Ajak Kuac county injured members of an unspecified group as they went to collect stolen animals at Unity state. The source does not provide further details, nor a precise location (coordinates for the disputed Twic State capital of Turalei (Warrap state) have been used at precision 3).

On Dec 9th, a youth militia (suspected of coming from the disputed Lakes state, and coded as such) attacked an unspecified area of Paloic county (Lakes state, coordinates for Paloich used at precision 2), killing one, and abducting four.

Around early December, armed cattle herders from Jonglei state harassed and tortured villagers as well as looted from civilians, according to the county commissioner for Nyepo. The herders appear to have set up camps in Rodo, Nyepo county (Central Equatoria, approx coordinates used based on humanitarian map). There is no detailed information on casualties.

On December 10th, a lone gunman shot and killed the Paramount Chief of Ajak Kuac county (Warrap state) at an unspecified location in the county. Security personnel were deployed to calm the situation, and the attacker was arrested.

On Dec 11th, armed youth (suspected of coming from Yirol West, and coded as Eastern Lakes communal militia) attacked two commercial vehicles at an unspecified location between Yirol and Rumbel (Lakes state, coordinates for Akot used at precision 2). Three civilians were injured in the attack.

On December 13th, an unidentified armed group (suspected to be form neighbouring Boma state) attacked women as they gathered fruit at Akwai-Deng village in Athooc North county (coordinates for Bor, Jonglei state, used). Two of the women were killed, and another wounded. There was no clear motive for the attack.

On December 13th, NAS claimed a recent build-up of government troops (SSPDF and Mathiang Anyoor paramilitaries) in parts of the former Central and Western Equatoria states including in the area of Lobonok (Central Equatoria, coordinates used), Tore (both Central Equatoria) and Rasoul (Western Equatoria).

Around 14th Dec, two sections of the Pakam clan (the Gak and Manuer sections) agreed to end long-running violence which has claimed dozens of lives over the previous five years. The event was sponsored by two international NGOs as well as UNMISS. The location of the event is not specified (coordinates for Maper, Lakes State, used. Maper is the county capital for Aloor county, which is home of one of the clan sections).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, rebels attacked multiple villages across Central Equatoria at unspecified areas in Kenyi, Lasu, Lobonok and Mugwo payams (all at prec2), and two other unspecified locations. Seven events coded at time prec3 across different months, with five assigned to the NAS at confirmed areas of activity, and two to the SPLM-IO at unconfirmed locations (coordinates for Yei and Liggi used at geoprec2). 50 fatalities spread across the seven events.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, rebels abducted 74 civilians across nine events in various locations in Central Equatoria (including Alero, Logo, Lasu, and Yembe (approx coordinates from humanitarian map used for Yembe at prec2), and several unspecified locations along the Yei-Kaya road. Nine events recorded (six with NAS as actor1, three with SPLM-IO as actor1) all at time prec3, with eight events using specific locations, and one event using Yei at geoprec3.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: During the month of December, SPLM-IO rebels were reported to have abducted ""dozens"" of civilians in and around Yei (Central Equatoria).
During the month of December, NAS rebels beat a civilian in Mukaya (Central Equatoria), after he refused to join the rebellion.

column6: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: During the month of December, two Ciec Dinka clans (the Kuacthii and Kuacdit of the Manyiel section) clashed in the area of Nyang (Lakes state), killing six.

On December 15th, gunmen attacked the fishing village of Magool Apuk (coordinates for Gogrial, Warrap state, used), killing two and wounding five others, and engaged in looting. The attackers are believed to come from the neighbouring (disputed) Northern Liech state.
At an unspecified time during the month of December, a boy was killed in the area of Lomili boma in Kidepo valley, Eastern Equatoria.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be SSPDF given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped and beat women in Darasalam (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Two events at time precision 3 have been coded, to avoid overlap with MSF source covering attacks in late November.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be SPLM-IO given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped and beat women in Thowmangor (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Two events at time precision 3 have been coded, to avoid overlap with MSF source covering attacks in late November.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF or SPLM-IO Taban Deng, given their presence in the area) raped and beat women in Tharkoat (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Three events at time precision 3 have been coded, with SSPDF and Taban Deng's forces alternating as actor1 and assoc actor 1

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Between October and December 2018, an unspecified armed group (likely to be either SSPDF, SPLM-IO, or SPLM-IO Taban Deng) raped and beat women in Padai (Unity state, approximate coordinates based on UN map used). Two events at time precision 3 have been coded, to avoid overlap with MSF source covering attacks in late November.

On December 16th, unknown gunmen shot and killed a school headteacher near Lobonok (Central Equatoria), as he travelled to a wedding. The motivation for the attack is unclear, though the spokesman for the army accused NAS rebels of being behind the attack (actor 1 coded as UAG).

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On December 16th, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed twice in the area of Yei (Central Equatoria) and at an unspecified location close to the borders between Western and Central Equatoria, with both sides accusing the other of initiating the violence. The SSPDF spokesman said that NAS forces ambushed govt soldiers in the area (and also of destroying a bridge at Lumumba), killing two SSPDF soldiers and wounding five. The NAS said their forces were assaulted at two locations (Mile 13 and Mile 20 on the Yei-Maridi road), and that they had inflicted ""heavy losses"" on the army (two events coded with one fatality apiece, with Yei at precision 2 as the location for one event, and Maridi (Western Equatoria) as the location for the second event, also at precision 2).

column16: Catholic Radio Network; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On December 16th, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed twice in the area of Yei (Central Equatoria) and at an unspecified location close to the borders between Western and Central Equatoria, with both sides accusing the other of initiating the violence. The SSPDF spokesman said that NAS forces ambushed govt soldiers in the area (and also of destroying a bridge at Lumumba), killing two SSPDF soldiers and wounding five. The NAS said their forces were assaulted at two locations (Mile 13 and Mile 20 on the Yei-Maridi road), and that they had inflicted ""heavy losses"" on the army (two events coded with one fatality apiece, with Yei at precision 2 as the location for one event, and Maridi (Western Equatoria) as the location for the second event, also at precision 2).

On December 16th, an SSPDF Brigadier General was shot by his bodyguard iat his house n Juba, for unclear reasons. The bodyguard then fled the scene. General assumed unarmed at moment of attack hence event has been recorded as VAC.

On December 16th, two gunmen (suspected of coming from nearby Iloli village) attacked a social event at the village of Oguruny in Torit East (Eastern Equatoria state), killing two and wounding two others.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On December 16th, NAS and SSPDF soldiers clashed in the area of Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Both sides accused the other of initiating the attack. The SSPDF said that two of its soldiers were killed and ten wounded; the NAS said that they had killed seven government soldiers and wounded ten (two fatalities coded), and captured a small number of weapons.

On December 17th, unidentified gunmen attacked the village of Manyjong in Malek county (coordinates for Malek, Lakes state, used). Three civilians were wounded, including a teacher and a pastor. The motive for the attack is unclear; youth from the neighbouring (disputed) Gok state are accused of being behind the attack.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: On December 17th, an unspecified armed group (likely to be SSPDF given their presence in the area, and coded as such) raped five women in Lang (Unity state), four of whom were pregnant.

column9: IGAD: Intergovernmental Authority on Development; Military Forces of Ethiopia (1991-); Military Forces of Kenya (2013-); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Women (International)
column17: On December 18th, four CTSAMVM staff were detained and beaten for four hours at the SSPDF compound in Luri (Central Equatoria), as they were investigating alleged breaches of the ceasefire. Several of the attackers were in military uniform. Three military officers from Sudan, Kenya and Ethiopia were the victims of the assault, as was their driver (of unspecified nationality). The victims were robbed, and the female officer made to strip naked.
On or around December 18th, an SSPDF soldier from Waat base was killed in unclear circumstances at an unspecified location in Akobo county, according to the SPLM-IO.

On December 18th, government soldiers from Waat base were accused of killing five civilians in the villages of Lony and Mantiwiet in Akobo Centre county, according to the SPLM-IO. Soldiers also detained six civilians, before releasing them. The event follows the alleged killing of an SSPDF soldier.
On December 19th, an unidentified group attacked a location in the vicinity of Lol-Kou in Aweng county. Four fisherman and one soldier were killed in the attack.

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column9: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
column17: On 19 December 2018, SSPDF officers (operating at the behest of SLM/A-Nur rebels, coded as assoc actor1) arrested 3 notable SLM/A-TC figures in Nimule (Magwi county, Eastern Equatoria state), in order to turn over the captives to a senior SLM/A-Nur commander. The rendition was prevented following the intervention of a different branch of the SSPDF.
On December 20th, NAS forces allegedly abducted nine civilians as they travelled on the Yei-Kaya road, according to local authorities. The NAS strongly deny the accusation.

On December 20th, two children were killed and five were seriously injured when they were playing with an unexploded rocket at Kachtong Payam in Duk Panyang county (coordinates for Pajut, Jonglei, used).

At an unspecified time in the week beginning December 17th, two people were killed in a family feud in Kimotong county (Eastern Equatoria). One of the families was connected to a former local politician.

column6: SPLM-FD: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (Former Detainees)
column17: On December 22nd, Madame Rebecca Garang returned to Juba after leaving the country following the start of the civil war, and was accompanied by several members of the SPLM-FDs. She was received by Tut Gatluak (an influential security advisor) as well as a minister.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: On December 23rd, unknown gunmen abducted between seven and nine people in the area of Yari (Central Equatoria). A police officer travelling with the victims reportedly killed an attacker while four civilians were wounded.Local authorities accused NAS of being behind the attack, NAS denied.

On December 23rd, police fired upon one another at the Mobil roundabout in Juba, in unclear circumstances. One police officer was killed, and two wounded (one source states that three were killed, the lower estimate has been used here).
On or before December 24th, a soldier raped an elderly woman at Nesitu (coordinates for Lokiliri, Central Equatoria, used). The soldier has been arrested.

On December 25th, a man threw a grenade into a group of civilians who had gathered for a Christmas celebration at Ifayi payam (coordinates for Ikotos, Eastern Equatoria, used), wounding two. Police have subsequently captured a suspect.

On December 25th, gunmen (suspected of coming from the disputed Northern Liech state) attacked an unspecified location in Aliny county (coordinates for Wunkur, Unity state, used). Two people were wounded, and two are missing. Over 1,000 head of cattle were stolen.
On December 25th, a gunman fired upon a house in the Jebel Dinka area of Juba, wounding three (one seriously). A suspect has been arrested.

column6: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On December 26th and 27th, raiders attacked Dinka Rek communities in Luajang East and North counties (coordinates for Ngabagok, Warrap state, used at precision 2) sparking at least two clashes. One clash was between the Dinka Rek and Dinka Pakam (from the disputed Western Lakes state), which resulted in six Dinka Pakam killed. The other clash was between the Dinka Rek and Hah Nuer from Bul South county (in the disputed Southern Liech state), killing five Dinka Rek. 36 were wounded, and 700 head of cattle stolen across the two events.
On December 26th, Sudanese refugees demonstrated against the NCP government in Sudan, at several refugee camps in Maban county (Upper Nile state).

On December 26th, Luanyjang and Pakam communal militias clashed at an unspecified location in Aloor county (coordinates for Maper, Lakes state, used). At least 12 were killed (seven from the Pakam, and five from the Luanyjang), and 45 injured. It is unclear what triggered the clashes.

column8: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On December 26th and 27th, raiders attacked Dinka Rek communities in Luajang East and North counties (coordinates for Ngabagok, Warrap state, used at precision 2) sparking at least two clashes. One clash was between the Dinka Rek and Dinka Pakam (from the disputed Western Lakes state), which resulted in six Dinka Pakam killed. The other clash was between the Dinka Rek and Hah Nuer from Bul South county (in the disputed Southern Liech state), killing five Dinka Rek. 36 were wounded, and 700 head of cattle stolen across the two events.

On December 26th and 27th, raiders attacked Luajang East and North counties (coordinates for Tonj, Warrap state used) in two separate events (one allegedly involving a group from the disputed Western Lakes state, and the other from the disputed Southern Liech state. There is no information regarding the date the different groups were said to have attacked). At least ten people died in the clashes, and 36 were wounded (fatalities split across the two events). 700 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen.

column9: Labour Group (South Sudan); Government of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On Dec 27th, alleged NAS rebels attacked a convoy of civilian vehicles in the area of Jumbo (Central Equatoria), killing a bussinesman. The vehicle was also carrying a senior official from the disputed Yei River state.

column6: Twic East Area Youth Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On December 27th, cattle raiders (suspected of coming from Boma state, and coded as a Murle militia) attacked Akoi cattle camp in Twic Centre (coordinates for Wanglei, Jonglei state, used). One of the attackers was killed, and a member of the local youth militia was wounded.

On Dec 27th, NAS forces attacked an SSPDF base at an unspecified location in Wonduruba county (Central Equatoria state), reportedly in retaliation for the killing of a suspected NAS informant by government troops on Nov 23rd. Seven SSPDF soldiers were killed in the attack.

On December 27th, gunmen attacked a vehicle at an unspecified location on the road between Pibor and Juba (coordinates for Pibor, Jonglei state, used, given the prominence of the (disputed) Boma State minister of information in the source). Three people were killed, and seven wounded.

column9: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On December 29th, an armed group attacked an unspecified area(s) along the Yei-Kaya road. An unspecified number of UNMISS personnel (nationality unspecified) were reported to have been abducted, and held for ranson, whilst looting of civilian homes also took place. The two factions of the SSNMC (one of which has joined the current peace agreement, the other breakaway group which has not) accused one another of being behind the attack (for the time being, an UAG is coded).
On or before December 30th, three people were burned to death in a house in the area of Kabo (coordinates for Audo Kabo, Central Equatoria, used). Motive unclear.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: On December 30th, prisoners escaped from Yambio Central Prison (Western Equatoria), in an event which involved a shoot-out with prison guards. Following the escape, unspecified security forces attacked the house of one of the escapees (a local musician), and shot him dead (recorded as one event).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Between September and December 2018, rebels abducted 74 civilians across nine events in various locations in Central Equatoria (including Alero, Logo, Lasu, and Yembe (approx coordinates from humanitarian map used for Yembe at prec2), and several unspecified locations along the Yei-Kaya road. Nine events recorded (six with NAS as actor1, three with SPLM-IO as actor1) all at time prec3, with eight events using specific locations, and one event using Yei at geoprec3.
On Dec 30th, a pastoralist was killed in Duk Pagak county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Pagak used at prec2), by unknown attackers. There is no further information.

On December 30th, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed in the area of Kenyi in Lainya county (Central Equatoria), according to the SSPDF. The army spokesman accused rebels of initiating the attack; there are no reports of casualties.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between December 2018 and early April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces abducted 41 civilians from areas in and around Yei and Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Reports indicate many were subject to abuse and/or torture whilst in detention. Four events coded at time prec3.

On December 30th, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed in the area of Loka (Central Equatoria), according to the SSPDF. The army spokesman accused rebels of initiating the attack; there are no reports of casualties.

On December 30th, SSPDF and NAS forces clashed in the areas of Katigiri and Onduraba (Central Equatoria), according to the NAS, who also accused the army of dislodging them from their positions (note that there is no information on the location of Katigiri. Accordingly, one event has been recorded at Onduraba). There are no reports of casualties.

On January 1st, a soldier shot and killed a Sudanese man, following what the source describes as a ""simple misunderstanding"". The event took place in the Khor Wiliang suburb of Juba; a suspect has been arrested.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), and Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).
On January 1st, a soldier threw a grenade into a market on the north-west outskirts of Juba, killing two, and wounding four. The suspect has been arrested, although the motive is unclear.
During the week beginning Dec 31st (2018), either two or three women were raped in Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Two soldiers have been arrested in connection with the attack.

On January 2nd, raiders (suspected of coming from Boma state, and coded here as a Murle militia) attacked Pajimaar payam in Duk Pagak county (Jonglie state, coordinates for Pagak used at prec2). After what is described as a long battle, one local youth was killed, and 250 head of cattle stolen. Duk youth are pursuing the raiders.

column7: Parek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column9: Palueel Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or before January 3rd, youth from the Palueel and Palek clans clashed at an unspecified location in Aweil East, in a fight involving sticks, and which was related to the ownership of a nearby market on the road to Abyei. 10 people were injured and taken to Malualkon hospital (Northern Bahr el Ghazal, coordinates used), and several people have been arrested.

On January 3rd, government soldiers and NAS rebels clashed in the vicinity of Kitigiri and Onduraba in Central Equatoria (coordinates for the latter used). According to the NAS spokesman, 15 soldiers were killed, and one rebel died in the clash.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio (South Sudan); CTSAMM
column17: On January 3rd, an unknown armed group attacked the village of Kisaro/Tishoro near Gorom (coordinates for Onduraba, Central Equatoria, used). 19 civilians were killed, and eight wounded. One witness reported being looted by the attackers. The government has accused NAS rebels, whilst the NAS and the PDM rebel groups claimed the attack was committed by government soldiers and/or pro-government militias (UAG used as actor 1). On Jan 8th, a ceasefire monitoring verification team was blocked from visiting the area by NSS agents at Luri.

On or around January 4th, youth from Geria and Ayaci counties (assumed armed) in the disputed Torit state fought at an unspecified location in Ayaci county (coordinates for Katire, Eastern Equatoria, used). Some houses burned down. There were no reports of casualties, nor of any details of the weapons used. The clashes were seemingly sparked over where the headquarters for Isore payam should be located.

On January 5th, raiders suspected of coming from Western Lakes State attacked Kumuku cattle camp in Anuol county (Lakes state). In the ensuing confrontation, local militia (coded here as Eastern Lakes Communal Militia) received support from nearby soldiers, and repulsed the attack, killing ten raiders (unclear division of casualties). Two local fighters were wounded.

On or around January 5th, youth from Ayaci and Geria counties torched houses in one another's villages (coordinates for Geria, Eastern Equatoria, used), as part of a dispute over the placement of the Isore payam headquarters. At least 179 dwellings were torched, displacing 600 people to Katire village.

On January 6th, raiders (suspected Murle from Boma state) attacked Lou Nuer herders in the area of Duachan, between Akobo West and East counties (coordinates for Akobo, Jonglei state, used). 35 people were killed in the attack, 78 were injured. Between this and a second event on the same day, 2,000 cattle were stolen. Boma state authorities deny that their youth were involved.

On January 6th, raiders (suspected Murle from Boma state) attacked Lou Nuer herders in the area of Piethgai, between Nyirol and Kolaliet. 3 people were killed, 8 were injured. Between this and a second event on the same day, 2,000 cattle were stolen. Boma state authorities deny that their youth were involved.

On January 7th, Murle raiders suspected of coming from Boma state attacked the area of Parateat in Duk county. A Nuer paramount chief was killed in the attack. There is no indication of a firefight; accordingly the event as been recorded as VAC.
On January 7th, armed men raped a 12 year-old girl in Karpeto (Central Equatoria). There are no further details.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On January 7th, NAS and SPLM-IO rebels clashed at an unspecified location in Mugwo county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Lu used at precision 2). Two NAS rebels died in the clash.
On January 8th, NAS and SSPDF forces were reported to have clashed in the vicinity of Yei (Central Equatoria).

On January 8th, bandits (some sources say Murle raiders) ambushed a passenger vehicle in the Kolmerek area (Jonglei state), killing five civilians, and wounding four. One source notes that an attacker was wounded, though in unclear circumstances.
During the week commencing January 7th, Turkana raiders from Kenya attacked an area in the vicinity of Nadapal (Eastern Equatoria), killing a child and wounding two others. Cattle also killed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On January 9th, NAS and SPLM-IO forces clashed in the Mundubai area of Kozi county (Western Equatoria). There were no reports of casualties.

On January 10th, armed men attacked a truck carrying provisions the Dr John Garang University, in the area of Bed-Laku near Mangalla (Central Equatoria). A police officer who was accompanying the truck exchanged fire with the attackers, and was wounded in the process. The officer is to be taken to Juba for treatment.
On January 10th, an unknown group attack Ayii boma (coordinates for Opari, Eastern Equatoria, used), killing the chief, and are suspected of abducting three men at the same time.

On January 11th, a soldier fired into a market in Aweil (Northern Bahr el Ghazal), following a dispute with a Sudanese trader. No-one was injured or killed. The soldier was arrested by Military Police.
On January 12th, CTSAMM reported that government forces (coded here as Military) made an unauthorized movement of forces to Yei (Central Equatoria), as part of a military build-up in the area.
On Jan 12th, unknown gunmen attacked a civilian vehicle at an unspecified location in Yirol West (Lakes state, coordinates for Yirol used at precision 2), injuring two passengers.

On or before January 14th, raiders (suspected of coming from Western Lakes state) attacked a village in Murkwich boma, Wulu county (coordinates for Wullu, Lakes state, used). A woman was killed and a 17 year-old girl injured. Cows stolen. 14 people have been arrested in connection with the incident.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On January 14th, trucks travelling from Wau to Ater-Moc were ambushed in the area of Tonj (Warrap), seemingly by bandits. The source reports that a national security officer was injured in the attack (assumed on-duty), and that goods were looted from the drivers of the trucks. Several people have been arrested.

On January 14th, cattle raiders (suspected of coming from both Northern and Southern Liech states) attacked four villages in Warrap state, including Wunthilek (coordinates used), Darbim, Majak-Nhial, and Yath-Ngek (approx. coordinates used). At least 105 people were killed, 47 were wounded. 2,300 animals were stolen by the raiders. Fatalities spread over four events.

On January 14th, cattle raiders (suspected of coming from both Northern and Southern Liech states) attacked four villages in Warrap state, including Wunthilek (coordinates used), Darbim, Majak-Nhial, and Yath-Ngek (approx. coordinates used). At least 105 people were killed, 47 were wounded. 2,300 animals were stolen by the raiders. Fatalities spread over four events.

On January 14th, cattle raiders (suspected of coming from both Northern and Southern Liech states) attacked four villages in Warrap state, including Wunthilek (coordinates used), Darbim, Majak-Nhial, and Yath-Ngek (approx. coordinates used). At least 105 people were killed, 47 were wounded. 2,300 animals were stolen by the raiders. Fatalities spread over four events.

On January 14th, cattle raiders (suspected of coming from both Northern and Southern Liech states) attacked four villages in Warrap state, including Wunthilek (coordinates used), Darbim, Majak-Nhial, and Yath-Ngek (approx. coordinates used). At least 105 people were killed, 47 were wounded. 2,300 animals were stolen by the raiders. Fatalities spread over four events.

During the month of January, several Lou Nuer traditional leaders (most likely alongside civilians) were attacked by a Murle group in the area of Likuangole (Jonglei state), as they were attempting to deliver food. Several killed including two assistant chiefs (unknown fatalities coded as 10). There are no further details.

column6: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column7: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column17: During mid-January 2019, Dinka raiders from Tonj and members of the SSPDF Tiger Division attacked Bul Nuer in the Loat/Load area of Mayom county (Unity state), killing around 270 and injuring an unspecified number. The source does not mention whether there was an exchange of fire.
During the month of January, NAS rebels were reported to have detained 10 civilians at Ombasi (Central Equatoria), whom they accused of supporting the government.

During the month of January, raiders (likely to have come from the disputed Southern and Northern Liech states, and coded as such) attacked Marial-Lou and Toch in the disputed Tonj state (Warrap state; coordinates for Marial-Lou used at prec2). Between this and a series of attacks on Jan 14th (coded separately), 146 people were reported to have been killed and 60 injured (41 fatalities coded to this event).

During the month of January, inter-communal clashes were reported at an unspecified part of Magwi county in the disputed Imatong state (Eastern Equatoria state, coordinates for Magwi town used at prec2), killing 7, and wounding an unspecified number. There is no further information, including on the identity of the groups (both coded as Imatong Communal Militias pending further information).

Between January 2019 and April 2019, NAS rebels were reported to have killed 11 civilians at 5 locations across Central Equatoria (including Abegi, Kisharu (coordinates for Lobonok used at prec2), Longamere, Yei town and the nearby area of Pedele (coordinates for Yei used at prec2) and Rokon). Five events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across events.

On January 15th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Tonj state) attacked Thakuer (Unity state, approximate coordinates used - some sources also point to Loat, Bul East county, Unity state). 28 people were killed in the attack, including five raiders in the ensuing fighting, and 58-60 wounded. 3,000 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

At an unspecified time in January, raiders attacked an unspecified area of the dusputed Bieh state (in the former Jonglei state; coordinates for Waat used at precision 2). The raiders abducted 11 children, six whom were subsequently rescued from cattle camps in Likuangole county (actor 1 coded as Murle Ethnic Militia, given the location of the abductees). There is no further information.
On January 16th, NAS forces attacked SSPDF soldiers at their base in Jumbo (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.
On January 16th, NAS rebels abducted 22 civilians and around the villages of Goja (Central Equatoria, coordinates used at prec2), Hai Tarawa, Lopapa and Pedele. There is no further information.

column6: UNMAS: United Nations Mine Action Service
column17: On January 16th, UNMAS defused a 50kg bomb on the outskirts of Juba. The bomb - which had been found by the SSPDF - was unexploded ordnance from the Second Sudanese Civil War (actor 2 coded as Military Forces of Sudan).

On January 17th (and/or Jan 18th, one event coded at time precision 2), NAS rebels clashed with SSPDF soldiers at an unspecified location in Otogo county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Luri used at precision 2). There are no reports of casualties.

On January 18th (and/or January 17th, one event coded at time precision 2), NAS rebels claimed that government forces attacked their position at Mukaya payam (Central Equatoria). Unclear if NAS forces repulsed the attack, or retreated from their positions before besieging government forces. There are no reports of casualties.
On January 18th, government soldiers raped an unspecified number of women at Karpeto (Central Equatoria). The accused have been arrested.
On January 18th, an unknown group abducted eight civilians in Goja (Central Equatoria). Seven were released two days later, whilst one female captive is still being held.

On January 19th, a Murle militia was suspected of killing four and wounding five others in the Duachan area of Akobo. 13 children were also reported to have been abducted. The victims were riding in a commercial vehicle. Note that authorities from the disputed Boma state (where the attackers likely originated) told authorities in the disputed Akobo state about an impending attack.
On January 19th, a landmine (possibly from the Second Sudanese Civil War) exploded in Bor (Jonglei state), wounding six women and children (some seriously).
