column6: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On January 19th, a UN peacekeeper shot and killed two South Sudanese labourers inside the UN base in south-western Juba. At present, there is no information as to the motive for the killing.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: On or around January 20th, NAS rebels claimed to have clashed with government forces in the area of Rokon (Central Equatoria). The NAS said they killed ten SSPDF soldiers, and captured ten members of the prison services, including a commander.

On January 20th, NAS forces claimed to have repulsed a government attack at an unspecified location along the Yei-Maridi road (though likely on the Central Equatoria side; coordinates for Yei used at precision 2). NAS forces claimed to have killed three Mathiang Anyoor paramilitaries, and forced SSPDF soldiers to retreat.
On January 20th, a man was killed by suspected Murle fighters in the area of Aguludiek close to Pochalla town (Jonglei state, coordinates used). There is no known motive for the attack.
On or around January 20th, residents of Lobira payam shot dead a man in Dongotono (coordinates for Kidepo, Eastern Equatoria, used).
On or around January 21st, four women were killed in Lobira (Eastern Equatoria), in a revenge attack conducted by armed residents of Dongotono.
On January 22nd, a female priest was shot and killed at her home in Hai Tawara (coordinates for Maridi, Western Equatoria state, used). No motive for the attack has yet been established.

At an unspecified time (though likely in late January), gunmen from Tonj East abducted three children from an unspecified location in the disputed Gok state (coordinates for Cueibet, Lakes state, used), and stole 150 head of cattle.

During late January (coded as 23rd Jan at time precision 3) government tanks attacked the village of Mukaya (Central Equatoria), seemingly as part of a sweep for rebels. There are no reports of casualties.

column8: Eastern Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On January 26th, inter-communal clashes were reported in Ulang (Jonglei state). It is unclear who the attackers were, though actor2 has been coded as Eastern Jikany Nuer militia.

On Jan 27th, 12 fishermen were killed by a militia from Bul South county (coded as Bul Nuer ethnic militia) at an unspecified location in Akop county (Warrap state, coordinates for Akop used at precision 2). There is no further information.

On January 27th, two Ciec Dinka sub-clans clashed in the area of Majak-Jok (coordinates for Yirol, Lakes state, used). The Kuac-Dit clan were reported to have attacked the Kuac-Thii, as part of a series of attacks beginning November 2018. One Kuac-Dit fighter was killed.

On January 28th, members of the Kajo-Keji community based in Juba demonstrated against the killing of two members of their community by a UN peacekeeper the previous week. The peaceful protest occurred at the UNMISS compound in Tongping.

column8: SPLM-FD: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (Former Detainees)
column17: On January 29th, Deng Alor announced that the SPLM-FDs (high-ranking politicians who have spent much of the war in exile following their arrest in late 2013) was reuniting with the SPLM party, following a meeting with President Salva Kiir.

On and before January 29th, reports emerged suggesting that the army was forcibly conscripting youth in the disputed Twic and Gogrial states. The army denies the accusation, stating they are collecting deserters whilst gathering information on their forces in the areas.

column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On January 29th, fighting between Pakam youth and local youth groups at four locations in Eastern Lakes state (Yali; Pagarau; Machuor and an unspecified location in Rumbek Central), killing 16 (fatalities split across four events), and wounding at least 20. Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On January 29th, fighting between Pakam youth and local youth groups at four locations in Eastern Lakes state (Yali; Pagarau; Machuor and an unspecified location in Rumbek Central), killing 16 (fatalities split across four events), and wounding at least 20. Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On January 29th, fighting between Pakam youth and local youth groups at four locations in Eastern Lakes state (Yali; Pagarau; Machuor and an unspecified location in Rumbek Central), killing 16 (fatalities split across four events), and wounding at least 20. Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).

column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On January 29th, fighting between Pakam youth and local youth groups at four locations in Eastern Lakes state (Yali; Pagarau; Machuor and an unspecified location in Rumbek Central), killing 16 (fatalities split across four events), and wounding at least 20. Soldiers tried to intervene in at least some locations; two soldiers were killed in the fighting, at unspecified locations (included in total toll).
On Jan 30th, government soldiers shelled Morsak (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.

On January 30th, NAS rebels claimed they ambushed SSPDF forces in the area of Aboroto (coordinates for Moroboo, Central Equatoria, used), and killed ""a dozen"" government soldiers (12 fatalities coded).

column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On January 30th, Pakam youth clashed once more with youth from Eastern Lakes state, in at least one location (coordinates for Pagarau, Lakes state, used at precision 2).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between December 2018 and early April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces abducted 41 civilians from areas in and around Yei and Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Reports indicate many were subject to abuse and/or torture whilst in detention. Four events coded at time prec3.

Between January 2019 and April 2019, NAS rebels were reported to have killed 11 civilians at 5 locations across Central Equatoria (including Abegi, Kisharu (coordinates for Lobonok used at prec2), Longamere, Yei town and the nearby area of Pedele (coordinates for Yei used at prec2) and Rokon). Five events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across events.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).
On January 30th, NAS rebels claimed they repulsed an attack by SSPDF forces in the area of Morsak (Central Equatoria), and inflicted ""heavy casualties"" on government forces (10 fatalities coded).
On January 30th, NAS rebels claimed they repulsed an attack by SSPDF forces in the area of Lujulu (Central Equatoria), and inflicted ""heavy casualties"" on government forces (10 fatalities coded).

column8: SSNDA: South Sudan National Democratic Alliance
column17: On January 31st, unspecified forces from the SSNDA rebel coalition repulsed an attack by government forces (source is unclear about SPLM-IO involvement), according to a statement released by the rebel group. The event took place in the Lujulu area (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.
From January 31st-February 2nd, NAS and SSPDF soldiers were reported to have clashed in Goja boma (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties. Coded as 3 events.

column8: SSNDA: South Sudan National Democratic Alliance
column17: On January 31st, unspecified forces from the SSNDA rebel coalition repulsed an attack by government forces (source is unclear about SPLM-IO involvement), according to a statement released by the rebel group. The event took place in the area of Kajo-Keji (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.
On January 31st, NAS rebels claimed they repulsed another attack by SSPDF forces in the area of Morsak (Central Equatoria).

On or around Jan 31st, SSPDF were reported to have been ""randomly"" shelling civilian villages in the vicinity of Yei (Central Equatoria), according to a statement by the SSNDA rebel coalition. There are no reports of casualties.

column8: SSNDA: South Sudan National Democratic Alliance
column17: On January 31st, unspecified forces from the SSNDA rebel coalition repulsed an attack by government forces (source is unclear about SPLM-IO involvement), according to a statement released by the rebel group. The event took place in Morobo county (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.
On Jan 31st, government soldiers entered Morsak (Central Equatoria), shot at civilians, burned dwellings, and looted belongings. There are no reports of casualties.

On or around Jan 31st, SSPDF soldiers attacked civilians (including raping women and girls) in the area of Yei (Central Equatoria), according to a statement issued by the SSNDA rebel group. There is no further information at this time (coded as one VAC event).

On February 1st, NAS rebels accused SSPDF and what they described as 'Mathiang Anyoor' of attackig their positions at Senema (Central Equatoria, approximate coordinates used), killing nine civilians and one NAS soldier, and wounding a further five soldiers (fatalities may have occurred in Senema or other parts of Central Equatoria that experience fighting between 31st Jan-2nd Feb (which have been recorded as separate events)).

On February 1st, cattle raiding youth (coded here as Tonj Communal Militia) were reported to have ""confronted"" a man on the Tonj-Augka road (Warrap state, coordinates for Aguka used). Note that the source is vague on details, and does not specify what happened during the incident.

On February 1st, gunmen attacked a commercial boat in the area of Jorwach as it travelled from Fangak to an unspecified location in Jonglei state (coordinates for Bor, Jonglei, used). One person was killed, and another wounded in the attack. The survivor is recovering in Bor hospital.
From January 31st-February 2nd, NAS and SSPDF soldiers were reported to have clashed in Goja boma (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties. Coded as 3 events.

column9: Aid Workers (South Suda); UN: United Nations
column17: ""One male UN national staff was assaulted by a group of four perpetrators near the University in Bor. According to reports, the assailants harassed and attacked the staff member because of percieved foreign ties and this link to 'stealing' jobs from nationals. The staff's minor injuries were treated at the UNMISS medical facility.""

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: February 2nd, NAS and SPLM-IO (or SSPDF) soldiers were reported to have clashed in Kebida (Western Equatoria). At least nine people were killed, including two civilians.
From January 31st-February 2nd, NAS and SSPDF soldiers were reported to have clashed in Goja boma (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties. Coded as 3 events.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On February 2nd, NAS rebels accused SPLM-IO forces of attacking their base in the area of Kajo-Keji (Central Equatoria). SPLM-IO rebels denied the accusation, claiming that the NAS do not have troops in the area.
On Feb 3rd, two SSPDF soldiers executed the chief of Girim payam (Central Equatoria), dismembering his body in the process.

On February 3rd, suspected Murle raiders attacked herders in the area of Guer in Pading county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Fobor used). The raiders killed four and wounded five, and stole 7,000 head of cattle.

On February 4th, NAS rebels accused government forces of attacking their position once again at Senema (Central Equatoria, approximate coordinates used). The source indicates that SSPDF soldiers were involved, and the NAS alleged that Mathiang Anyoor were also involved in the attack. NAS rebels said they inflicted ""heavy casualties"" upon the Mathiang Anyoor (coded as 10 fatalities).
On Feb 4, Soldiers attacked Girim, looting and burning properties in the village.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On Feb 4th, NAS rebels attacked National Security Service positions at an unspecified location in Lobonok county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Lobonok used at precision 2). There is no further information, including whether or not there were casualties.

column6: SSUA-Gadet: Southern Sudan United Army (IO Faction)
column17: On or before February 5th, John Gattial Riek - the second highest-ranked military official within Peter Gadet's SSUM/A - announced that he had resigned his position, citing abused by rebel troops against civilians in the North-South border region, and Gadet's refusal to send senior staff to Juba as part of the pre-transitional phase of the peace process.
During early February, SSPDF soldiers beat two civilians (including an elderly man) in Ombasi (Central Equatoria), and forced them to carry food the soldiers had looted.
On Feb 6th, two soldiers killed a sub-chief in Girim boma (Central Equatoria). The county commissioner said the soldiers were drunk, and have been arrested.

On February 7th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state) attacked a cattle camp in the Lon Mawien area in the central-western area of the disputed Tonj state (coordinates for Tonj, Warrap state, used at precision 2). The raiders killed four, and stole approximately 200 head of cattle.

On February 6th or 7th, a group of butchers attacked the Mayor of Yambio, a local official, and the chairperson of the Chamber of Commerce in Yambio (Western Equatoria), following a dispute (seemingly over the introduction of new safety rules for food vendors). One source mentions the group used machetes and sticks, and caused serious injuries to the Mayor.

On Feb 8th and 9th, SSPDF soldiers attacked NAS positions in the areas of Wudabi (coordinates for Aloto, Central Equatoria, used) and Lujulu. According to the NAS, seven SSPDF were killed, and 13 civilians also died (fatalities distributed evenly across the four events).

On Feb 8th, eight people were reported to have died in cattle raids (coded as one event, involving Eastern Lakes Communal Militia and civilians) at an unspecified location in the disputed Eastern Lakes state (coordinates for Yirol, Lakes state, used). There is no further information.

On Feb 8th and 9th, SSPDF soldiers attacked NAS positions in the areas of Wudabi (coordinates for Aloto, Central Equatoria, used) and Lujulu. According to the NAS, seven SSPDF were killed, and 13 civilians also died (fatalities distributed evenly across the four events).

On Feb 8th and 9th, SSPDF soldiers attacked NAS positions in the areas of Wudabi (coordinates for Aloto, Central Equatoria, used) and Lujulu. According to the NAS, seven SSPDF were killed, and 13 civilians also died (fatalities distributed evenly across the four events).

On Feb 8th and 9th, SSPDF soldiers attacked NAS positions in the areas of Wudabi (coordinates for Aloto, Central Equatoria, used) and Lujulu. According to the NAS, seven SSPDF were killed, and 13 civilians also died (fatalities distributed evenly across the four events).

On Feb 10th, raiders suspected of coming from Boma state (coded here as a Murle ethnic militia) attacked a cattle camp in Pading county (Jonglei state), killing one, and stealing 3,500 head of cattle.

On Feb 11th, NAS forces said they repulsed an ambush by an SSPDF reconnaissance unit, in the area of Mundri (Western Equatoria). NAS claimed to have killed seven ""government militiamen"" (coded here as regular soldiers), and captured weapons from their attackers.
On Feb 11th, raiders suspected of coming from Boma state (coded here as a Murle ethnic militia) attacked a cattle camp in Pieri (Jonglei state), killing one, and stealing 500 head of cattle.

During the week beginning 11th Feb, a commercial vehicle was attacked and burned at an unspecified location on the Maridi-Mundri road (Western Equatoria, coordinates for Maridi used at precision 2). The source does not specify which group was responsible, but notes that SPLM-IO and NAS forces have been active in the area (actor 1 coded as UAG).

On Feb 11th or 13th, an armed group (allegedly from the Ambororo ethnic group, who had recently been expelled from the area) attacked a commercial vehicle in the River Duma area of Western Equatoria (note that the source says the attack took place at around 3km distance from the CAR border, hence event is coded at Tambura prec2). Three traders were killed in the attack.

During the month of February 2019, and amidst a forcible military recruitment drive in the areas of Gogrial, Twic and Tonj, soldiers beat a 17 year-old boy in or near Aguek near Gogrial (Warrap state) for resisting recruitment.
At an unspecified time in February, six people (coded as civilians) were killed in Morsak (Central Equatoria), five of whom were dumped in a toilet. There is no further information.
At an unspecified time in February, SSPDF soldiers attacked Morsak (Central Equatoria), beating at least one civilian (and threatening to kill him). There is no further information.

On Feb 15th, armed youth clashed with police in or near Ngarik payam (Eastern Equatoria, approx coordinates for Kimotong used based on OCHA map), after police arrested suspected highwaymen in Ngarik. Six people were reported to have died in the clash (including a 7 year-old child), and five were wounded.

Between January 2019 and April 2019, NAS rebels were reported to have killed 11 civilians at 5 locations across Central Equatoria (including Abegi, Kisharu (coordinates for Lobonok used at prec2), Longamere, Yei town and the nearby area of Pedele (coordinates for Yei used at prec2) and Rokon). Five events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across events.
On Feb 15th, four SSPDF soldiers killed a farmer in Goja (Central Equatoria), and stole belongings from his family.

Between January and April 2019, NAS rebels abducted 11 civilians across western areas of Western Equatoria (coordinates for Maridi used at precision 2) and areas around Yei in Central Equatoria (coordinates for Mugwo used at prec2). A number of abductees were raped whilst in captivity. Coded as two VAC/Sexual Violence events.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

On Feb 18th, a breakaway faction of the NAS rebellion signed a peace agreement with the government in Yei (Central Equatoria). The group is calling itself the Equatoria Non-Allied Forces, although there is no further information on the group (note that they have not been coded as a new actor). The NAS issued a statement claiming that the faction was expelled from the NAS in March 2018.

At an unspecified time  (implied to be late February, and coded accordingly at precision 3) armed men believed to be SSPDF soldiers (coded as such) attacked 11 civilians at an area between Yei and Mukaya (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Yei used at precision 2). The civilians were beaten and robbed.

During the week Feb 25th, an armed group killed eight people and wounded a further eight in what is described as a cattle raid (or raids, coded as one event pending further information), at an unspecified location in the disputed Tonj state (coordinates for Tonj, Warrap state, used). The governor of Tonj state claimed that the group came from the disputed Southern Liech state (actor 1 coded accordingly), which has been denied by the information minister for Southern Liech state. There are no further details.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column9: SPLM-FD: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (Former Detainees)
column17: On Feb 20th, three factions of the SPLM political party agreed to (re)unite. These comprise the SPLM itself (the ruling party), the Former Detainees, and Taban Deng's faction of the SPLM-IO. Note that this does not include the larger SPLM-IO headed by Riek Machar.

Around 20th Feb, NAS forces said they had ambushed an SSPDF patrol at an unspecified location in Morobo county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Morobo used). There are no reports of fatalities. The rebels have alleged that government fores have been engaging in abuses against civilians in the area.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On February 20th, NAS rebels attacked SPLM-IO forces in the area of Wiro payam (Western Equatoria state), and engaged in looting activities. There are no reports of casualties.
On Feb 20th, gunmen wearing police and military uniforms(coded as such) shot dead a Ugandan truck driver in Rumbek. The victim was shot four times in the neck, seemingly for refusing to pay a bribe.

""One INGO staff member distributing food in the morning inside the PoC site was assaulted by an IDP. The reason for the assault is unknown, and the staff member's minor injuries were treated locally.""

column6: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition- Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: On Feb 23rd, internal fighting broke out within a unit aligned to Taban Deng's faction of the SPLM-IO, in the area of Thakuer (Unity state). A senior military figure aligned to Taban Deng (Brigadier General Pey Gai according to one source, though another sources names him as Major General Biel Gai Malual) was killed in the fighting, which appears to centre upon a dispute over whether or not to return stolen cattle seized by members of the group. There are no other reports of fatalities.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service; Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On Feb 24th, an unknown gunman (one source suggests there were several gunmen) shot three people at a nightclub in Yambio (Western Equatoria state). One person - who was employed by the National Security Service - was killed, and two people were wounded (an individual reported to be an SSPDF who was the bodyguard of the governor of the disputed Gbudue state (one source describes him as a police officer rather than a soldier), and a female civilian). Note: actor 2 coded as civilians as the officers were off-duty at the time.
During late February, an SSPDF soldier beat and raped a woman he had forced to carry looted property. The event occurred in Morsak (Central Equatoria).

During late February and early March, nine women were reported to have been raped by government soldiers in or around Yei (Central Equatoria). Two events coded at time precision 2 and location precision 2.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Further clashes were reported between SPLM-IO and NAS rebels in the area of Wiro payam (Western Equatoria state), following on from fighting on Feb 20th. The source does not specify how many events took place in the time of fighting (between Feb 20th-28th), one event coded on Feb 28th at time prec2. There are no reports of casualties.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between December 2018 and early April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces abducted 41 civilians from areas in and around Yei and Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Reports indicate many were subject to abuse and/or torture whilst in detention. Four events coded at time prec3.

Between January 2019 and April 2019, NAS rebels were reported to have killed 11 civilians at 5 locations across Central Equatoria (including Abegi, Kisharu (coordinates for Lobonok used at prec2), Longamere, Yei town and the nearby area of Pedele (coordinates for Yei used at prec2) and Rokon). Five events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across events.

Between January and April 2019, NAS rebels abducted 11 civilians across western areas of Western Equatoria (coordinates for Maridi used at precision 2) and areas around Yei in Central Equatoria (coordinates for Mugwo used at prec2). A number of abductees were raped whilst in captivity. Coded as two VAC/Sexual Violence events.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

On March 1st, a cattle camp was raided at an unspecified location in Abiemnhom county (Unity state), by raiders from Mayom county (coded here as Bul Nuer militia). One civilian was killed, and four soldiers injured, two of whom subsequently died of their injuries on March 3rd and 4th respectively. Given the apparent involvement of soldiers, the event has been coded as a battle between the militia and SSPDF, with three fatalities.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On March 2nd, fighting between police and soldiers took place at an unspecified location in Abiemnhom county (Unity state). The details in the sources are convoluted, but suggest that civilians from Mayom county fled to the police station fearing reprisals (following a raiding incident the previous day). Soldiers appear to have attacked the police station, resulting in three fatalities (two soldiers and one civilian), and five injuries (two NSS officers and two bodyguards of a county commissioner).

On March 3rd, an armed group (suspected of coming from Mayom county, and coded as Bul Nuer militia) killed a man and wounded his wife at an unspecified location in Abiemnhom county (Unity state). There are no further details.

On March 3rd or 4th, unknown gunmen attacked civilians fleeing the area of Wunduruba(Central Equatoria), wounding two. There is no further information, nor information on any event which may have forced the civilians to flee.

On March 4th, an armed group (suspected of coming from Mayom county, and coded as Bul Nuer militia) shot two women at an unspecified location in Abiemnhom county (Unity state), wounding one and killing the other. There are no further details.

column9: Government of South Sudan (2011-); Christian Group (South Sudan)
column17: On March 4th, an unidentified gunman (or gunmen, the source is unclear on this) shot and killed a 55 year-old woman at her home in Maridi (Western Equatoria). The victim worked for the Ministry of Finance for the disputed Maridi state, and was involved in the Episcopal Church of South Sudan.

column6: SSUA-Gadet: Southern Sudan United Army (IO Faction)
column17: On March 4th, General Tut Gatjual announced he and 200 other political and military officers had split from Peter Gadet's SSUM/A, and were in talks with Gabriel Changson's SSOA to join the umbrella group.

On March 5th, SSPDF and NAS rebels clashed near Katigiri (Central Equatoria state), causing displacement of civilians in the area. The source does not specify the number of injuries or fatalities (10 fatalities coded).

On March 5th, SSPDF and NAS rebels clashed near Gumba (Western Equatoria state), causing displacement of civilians in the area. The source does not specify number injuries or fatalities (10 fatalities coded).

On March 5th, NAS rebels ambushed the commissioner of Wonduruba county at an unspecified location along the Lainya-Wonduruba road (Central Equatoria state, coordinates for Wonduruba used at prec2). There are no reports of casualties.

On March 6th, armed pastoralists attacked several villages (including Warbet and Alel-Dong bomas) in Kuajiena (aka Kwajina) county (Western Bahr el Ghazal), killing at least two. Five women and two girls were raped by the attackers. The attackers then destroyed farms and robbed the inhabitants of the area, including local markets. 3,530 people were reported to have fled to Kwajina town.

During the week beginning March 4th, a vehicle was attacked at Liggi (Central Equatoria) by unknown gunmen (described both as ""bandits"" and ""anti-peace elements"" by the state police commissioner, and coded as a UAG), wounding two civilians.

On or after 6 March 2019, armed pastoralists from Kuajena county in the disputed Wau state killed a pastoralists from Tonj in the area of Akou (no coordinates found, coordinates for Tonj (Warrap state) used). The attack was in retaliation for a raid by pastoralists from Tonj.

On March 6th, SSPDF soldiers clashed with armed youth (coded as Southern Liech communal militia) at Rubkuey (Unity state, approximate coordinates from Reach humanitarian map used at prec2). Two youth were killed in the clash.

During the week beginning March 4th, NAS rebels and government forces clashed in several locations around Yei (including Pisa, Logo, Kobo, and Kirikwa (all Central Equatoria)). 750 people were reportedly displaced in the fighting. Four events coded at time precision 2.

During the week beginning March 4th, NAS rebels and government forces clashed in several locations around Yei (including Pisa, Logo, Kobo, and Kirikwa (all Central Equatoria)). 750 people were reportedly displaced in the fighting. Four events coded at time precision 2.

During the week beginning March 4th, soldiers attacked a vehicle travelling along the Yei-Kaya road (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Yei used), killing two passengers, one of whom was a soldier (actor 2 coded as civilians, with military forces as assoc actor 2). Two suspects have been arrested, in a dispute which has been described as a family dispute.
During early March, SSPDF soldiers attacked an unspecified village in Otogo county (coordinates for Goja used at precision 2), burning crops and looting property.
In early March, a soldier attempted to rape a woman in Lorega (Central Equatoria; coordinates for Mukaya used at precision 2). The soldier fled when the father intervened.

During early March, SSPDF accosted three female civilians as they were fleeing Yondori village to Yei (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Mukaya county used at precision 2). They forced the women to carry supplies, and then beat them with sticks to chase them away.

During the week beginning March 4th, NAS rebels and government forces clashed in several locations around Yei (including Pisa, Logo, Kobo, and Kirikwa (all Central Equatoria)). 750 people were reportedly displaced in the fighting. Four events coded at time precision 2.

During late February and early March, nine women were reported to have been raped by government soldiers in or around Yei (Central Equatoria). Two events coded at time precision 2 and location precision 2.

During the week beginning March 4th, NAS rebels and government forces clashed in several locations around Yei (including Pisa, Logo, Kobo, and Kirikwa (all Central Equatoria)). 750 people were reportedly displaced in the fighting. Four events coded at time precision 2.

On March 8th, raiders (coded as Southern Liech communal militia, although the source is not clearly worded) attacked an unspecified area in Luany-Jang North county in the disputed Tonj state (coordinates for Ngabagok, Warrap state, used at precision 2). Seven people were killed, and five wounded.

On March 9th, unknown gunmen attacked the area Ngarilim of Pibor town (Jonglei state), killing a soldier, and wounding two civilians. The source says that ""a family"" was attacked, though there is no further information as to the motive. The state information minister accused the SPLM-IO of being involved, though this is not confirmed (actor 1 coded as UAG).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: At an unspecified time in March (coded as March 9th at time precision 2, to coincide with SPLM-IO activity in the area), SPLM-IO soldiers were reported to have raped female civilians in Wiro payam (Western Equatoria state), amidst clashes with NAS rebels in the area.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On March 9th and 10th, SPLM-IO rebels attacked NAS rebels at Wiro, Minga, Mollo and Garanya (Western Equatoria state), in retaliation for NAS recruitment activities. Two events coded, one using coordinates for Wiro, the other using approximate coordinates for Minga based on UN OCHA and Reach map at prec2

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On March 9th and 10th, SPLM-IO rebels attacked NAS rebels at Wiro, Minga, Mollo and Garanya (Western Equatoria state), in retaliation for NAS recruitment activities. Two events coded, one using coordinates for Wiro, the other using approximate coordinates for Minga based on UN OCHA and Reach map at prec2.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On March 10th, SPLM-IO rebels attacked a commercial convoy at Ligi (Central Equatoria). There is no further information.

column9: Apuk-Padoch Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On March 10th and 11th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Northern and Southern Liech states, and coded as such) attacked unspecified locations in Akop county (Warrap state), killing 12 and wounding 11 (fatalities spread across two events), and stealing 190 head of cattle.

column9: Apuk-Padoch Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On March 10th and 11th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Northern and Southern Liech states, and coded as such) attacked unspecified locations in Akop county (Warrap state), killing 12 and wounding 11 (fatalities spread across two events), and stealing 190 head of cattle.

column9: UN: United Nations; Labour Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 11 March 2019, a truck driver contracted by an unspecified UN agency was abducted by unknown gunmen close to Mogiri in Juba county (Central Equatoria state). The driver was released on 13 March 2019.

On March 12th, a soldier shot a colleague dead in unclear circumstances, during a disarmament operation at an unspecified location in the disputed Tonj state (coordinates for Tonj, Warrap state, used at prec2). The source suggests that another soldier died in the incident (two fatalities coded). The soldier has been arrested.
On March 12th, students from the University of Juba and the relocated Upper Nile University protested in Juba (Central Equatoria), against an increase in tuition fees. [size=no report]

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On March 12th, ""attacks"" occurred at an unspecified location near Pibor (Jonglei state), resulting in three SPLM-IO rebel fatalities and one SSPDF injury. There is no further information, including the number of incidents that occurred (one event coded).

On March 15th, unknown gunmen attacked a civilian vehicle as it travelled on the Juba-Pibor road, at an unspecified location implied as being close to Pibor (coordinates for Gumuruk, Jonglei state, used at precision 2). Two passengers were wounded. A local official accused the SPLM-IO of being responsible (coded as UAG pending further information).
At an unspecified time in March, SSPDF detained two civilians from Pisak (Central Equatoria), and took them to the barracks in Yei. They have remained there without charge as of early June 2019.

Between January 2019 and April 2019, NAS rebels were reported to have killed 11 civilians at 5 locations across Central Equatoria (including Abegi, Kisharu (coordinates for Lobonok used at prec2), Longamere, Yei town and the nearby area of Pedele (coordinates for Yei used at prec2) and Rokon). Five events coded at time prec3, with fatalities distributed across events.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: On March 16th, gunmen (suspected by authorities to be pastoralists from the disputed Tonj state, and coded as such) attacked an IDP camp in the area of Maranyi (Western Bahr el Ghazal, coordinates for Kuajiena used at precision 2). 15 civilians were killed, around 20 injured. The SPLM-IO also claimed that 13 children and six women were abducted. Details inconsistent across sources.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or around March 16th, SPLM-IO fighters clashed with armed pastoralists from the disputed Tonj state, in the area of Rabaganya (no geographic information found, coordinates for Kuajiena, Western Bahr el Ghazal, used at precision 2, given that the incident comes as part of a series of clashes in Kuajiena county). Four armed pastoralists were killed in the firefight.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On March 17th, gunmen (suspected by authorities to be pastoralists from the disputed Tonj state, and coded as such) attacked an IDP camp in the area of Akouya (Western Bahr el Ghazal, approximate coordinates used). Nine civilians were killed (one report says 15), 6-20 injured. Details inconsistent across sources.

On March 17th, unknown gunmen (alleged to be raiders from the disputed Bieh state, and coded as such) attacked civilians at an unspecified location in Doma county, with one report saying the event occurred in Doma itself (Upper Nile state, approximate coordinates for Doma used at precision), killing 16 civilians, and wounding seven.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On March 17th, the SPLM-IO claimed to have ""repulsed"" the gunmen (allegedly raiders from the disputed Bieh state, and coded as such) who attacked Doma county earlier that day (Upper Nile state, approximate coordinates for Doma used at precision 2). There is no further information, including whether there were casualties.

On 17 March 2019, armed pastoralists from Tonj attacked an unspecified location in Kuajiena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), killing nine civilians and wounding six. The attack comes amidst escalating violence in the area.

On or before March 17th, suspected soldiers attacked Sika Maridi village, forcing 3,000 civilians to flee to Yei. Note that it is unclear whether there was one or several events; whether there were any casualties; and whether or not sexual violence occurred in this specific incident.

column6: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Ajuong Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On March 18th, Ciec Dinka from Eastern Lakes clashed with Ajuong Dinka from Jonglei state, at an unspecified location in Malek county (coordinates for Malek, Lakes state, used at precision 2). The clashes are part of a dispute over the ownership of the Liet-Buoi swamp. Two militiamen died (one from each side), and five Ajuong Dinka were wounded. Police intervened, and established a larger presence in the area.

During the week beginning March 18th, a trader was killed in the area of Ringasi (Western Equatoria), by unknown gunmen. Similar incidents by political actors are often reported in the region. There is no further information.

On March 23rd, a soldier (who was bodyguard to a general) fired at a group of men who were engaged in a brawl (coded as civilians) in Bor (Jonglei state), killing one and wounding another. The soldier fled the scene, and was later arrested in the disputed Eastern Lakes state.

On March 23rd, unknown gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle on the road between Rumbek and Tonj, approximately 20 km outside of Tonj (Warrap state, coordinates for Wun Shol used at precision 2). A soldier (assumed to be guarding the truck) was killed in the attack, and the truck (which was operated by a Somali) was looted.

On March 24th, fighters from the Pari ethnic group attacked members of the Logir ethnic group at Lokila in Torit county (Eastern Equatoria). 20 people were killed (one report says 28), 17 of whom were from the Pari and 3 from the Logir (including the village chief), with 10 injured (eight Pari, and two Logir). The attack was likely in retaliation for a recent raid.

In late March, Amobororo militias attacked Yubo, Mogoroko and Naziazia villages (Western Equatoria state), and were alleged to have killed 21 civilians. Three events coded at time prec2, in Yubo and Naziaza at geoprec1 and Sakure at geoprec2, with fatalities distributed across the three events.

On March 26th, SAF soldiers were reported to have fired upon South Sudanese tax collectors in the area of Chimadi (Upper Nile state), whilst they were searching for smugglers in the area. There are no reports of casualties.

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: On March 26th, two White Army militiamen suspected of belonging to the Cie-wang section of the Nuer attacked a boat carrying a number of SPLM-IO MP's returning to Nasir following a peace dissemination meeting. One MP was killed (Simon Deng Bol Jaak) along with his military bodyguard and an SPLM-IO officer. A camerman (and perhaps also the boat driver) was wounded and another bodyguard is reported missing. The event took place in the area of Birjok village (Upper Nile, coordinates for Mandeng used at precision 2). Two people have been arrested.
On March 26th, SSPDF and SAF soldiers clashed at Atam (Upper Nile state; no geographic information found, coordinates for Renk used at prec2).

In late March, Amobororo militias attacked Yubo, Mogoroko and Naziazia villages (Western Equatoria state), and were alleged to have killed 21 civilians. Three events coded at time prec2, in Yubo and Naziaza at geoprec1 and Sakure at geoprec2, with fatalities distributed across events.

On March 29th, security forces (coded here as military) beat football players during a soccer match in Bor (Jonglei state) (and possibly also beat youth attending the match), during a dispute between the local minister for sport and footballers seemingly over work to be undertaken on the football pitch for an event, whilst a football match was ongoing. Security forces also fired weapons over the heads of the crowd.

In late March, Amobororo militias attacked Yubo, Mogoroko and Naziazia villages (Western Equatoria state), and were alleged to have killed 21 civilians. Three events coded at time prec2, in Yubo and Naziaza at geoprec1 and Sakure at geoprec2, with fatalities distributed across events.

On March 30th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as a Murle militia) attacked and killed a man who was hunting on the outskirts of Pajut (Jonglei state, location assigned precision 2, as it is unclear how far from Pajut the event occurred).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between December 2018 and early April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces abducted 41 civilians from areas in and around Yei and Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Reports indicate many were subject to abuse and/or torture whilst in detention. Four events coded at time prec3.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

On March 31st, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as a Murle militia) attacked a local militia moving from Duk Payuel to Pajut (coordinates for Pajut, Jonglei state, used at precision 2). In the ensuing firefight, two raiders were killed, and one member of the local militia was injured.

column9: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Luo Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 April 2019, armed pastoralists from Tonj attacked Lou IDPs at a school at an unspecified location in Kuajinena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), killing at least 11. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On April 1st, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians in Akuoya (Western Bahr el Ghazal, approximate coordinates based on IOM map). There were no reports of injuries or fatalities. The local commissioner said that ""the national security managed to contain the situation"", though it is unclear whether security services clashed with the attacking group.

At an unspecified time (though likely to be in late March or early April, and coded as April first at timeprec3) a clash (or clashes) occurred between militias from Manyangok and Wahn Alel counties (both actors coded as Tonj militia) killing 9 and wounding 22. The clashes were related to disputes on grazing and farmland areas. One event coded in Wun Shol in Mayangok county (Warrap state) at geoprec2.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column9: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Luo Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or after 2 April 2019, NSS personnel were tasked with guarding the Lou IDP victims of an attack on 1 April, but were instead reported to have been torturing their protectees and forcing them to undertake labour duties, until the eventual withdrawal of NSS agents in August 2019. The victims were based at a school at an unspecified part of Kuajiena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal).

On or before April 4th, youth from the Pakam Dinka clan from the disputed Western Lakes state raided Pagarau (Lakes state), clashing with youth from Eastern Lakes State. One person was killed in the battle, although their affiliation is not specified. Authorities later intervened to stabilise the situation.
On April 4th, a suspected soldier in uniform raped an 11 year-old boy in Yambio (Western Equatoria). There is no clear motive behind the attack. Authorities are investigating the incident.

On April 5th, an armed group raped an 11 year-old girl in Yambio (Western Equatoria). Note that a similar event the previous day was carried out by soldiers, but this source does not specify whether soldiers were also involved in this attack (actor 1 coded as UAG, pending further information). There is no clear motive behind the attack. Authorities are investigating the incident.

On April 9th, raiders attacked Luwaacodou cattle camp in the southern area of Jebel Buma county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Boma used at precision 2). In the ensuing firefight, at least 50 were reported killed; between 20 and 26 injured across both sides; and 2 children were reported to have been abducted (both actors coded as Murle ethnic militia).

On April 9th, youth suspected of coming from the Pakam Dinka clan from the disputed Western Lakes state raided the village of Thou-Abutkok in the disputed Eastern Lakes State (coordinates for Thou, Lakes state, used at precision 2). The raiders killed a pastoralist, and stole 108 head of cattle.

On April 10th, further fighting took place in western areas of Jebel Buma county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Boma used at precision 2). The events followed serious clashes the previous day in southern parts of the county; those raided the previous day were reported to be pursuing their attackers. There is no information on the numbers killed or wounded (both actors coded as Murle ethnic militia).
On April 11th, three people were reported to have been killed in a raid in Duk Padiet (Jonglei state). There is no further information (event coded as VAC involving UCM).

On April 12th, raiders suspected of coming from the disputed Wau state (and coded as such) attacked the village of Bolkok in Wanhalel county (Warrap state, coordinates for Pankeir used at precision 2). Two people were killed and three injured, and approx 25 head of cattle were stolen. (Note that minister for information of the disputed Tonj state implied that opposition elements - presumably SPLM-IO - were behind the attack, but his reasoning is speculative. Actor 1 has accordingly been coded as Wau state communal militia).

On April 13th, youth clashed at an unspecified location in Nyang county in the eastern area of Lakes state (coordinates for Nyang, Lakes state, used at precision 2). One person was killed in the clashes. The source indicates that one of the belligerents came from a neighbouring state, but does not say which one (actor 2 coded as UCM pending further information).
On April 13th, NAS rebels abducted five civilians near Pisak (Central Equatoria state).
On April 13th, NAS rebels ambushed SSPDF soldiers in Kirikwa (Central Equatoria state), killing two government soldiers.

On 13 April 2019, youth clashed at an unspecified location in the disputed Malek county in the Yirol East area of Lakes state. There are no reports of injuries. The source indicates that one of the belligerents came from a neighbouring state, but does not say which one (actor 2 coded as UCM pending further information).
On April 13th, youth from Aliab and Jej areas clashed at an unspecified location in the eastern area of Lakes state (coordinates for Aliab, Lakes state, used). One person was killed in the clashes.

On April 13th or 14th, four men were arrested (the source suggests this was because they were suspected of being rebels) and taken to the police station at Tambura town (Western Equatoria state). The following day, the bodies of the men were found in the area of Mabai (30 km south-west of Tambura). A local community has accused the governor of the disputed Tambura state of personally killing the men; the governor has said an independent investigation of the incident is required (pending further information, actor 1 has been coded as Police, given that the men were taken to the police station on Apr 13th).

On April 14th, youth raiders in Tonj (coded here as Tonj communal militia) attacked pastoralists in Pagol county, looting a small number of cattle. The source notes that one person was injured in an attack on Buollo village in Pagol county (no geographic information found; coordinates for Pagol, Warrap state, used at precision 2).

On April 13th and/or 14th, communities from Ajak and Kongdeer clashed in the vicinity of Wathmuok (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), over a proposal to establish a new county headquarters at Wathmuok, as part of a dispute which the source says has been ongoing for several years. Five people were injured in the clashes in a fight which involved basic hand weapons, although the dates in which the injuries occurred are not specified (one event has been recorded for the weekend of the 13th/14th, and a separate event for the 15th).

On April 14th, raiders suspected of coming from the disputed Western Lakes state (and coded as such) attacked an unspecified location in Panyijiar county (coordinates for Kuthai, Unity state, used at precision 2), killing four and severely wounding one. Eight people are reported to be missing, and the source suggests that a number of people drowned whilst fleeing the attackers across a river (likely the River Moch). 350 head of cattle were stolen.

On April 15th, clashes broke out between pastoralists in the area of Manya in Molbang payam (Warrap state, coordinates for Molbang used at precision 2), in an apparent dispute of grazing and water access in the area. The source indicates that one of the parties came from a neighbouring (disputed) state, but does not specify which one (the area borders the disputed Northern Liech and Ruweng states; actor 2 coded as UCM pending further information). One person died and eight were injured in the violence.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: During the month of April 2019, SPLM-IO (Taban Deng) forces were linked to forcible recruitment activities of refugees living in north Sudan as well as abductions of women and children. Upon their arrival in Rubkona town they were taken to the Tong area, with some men being taken for recruitment, and men resisting recruitment as well as women and children being detained for several months, until their eventual escape by August 2019.
During the month of April, six Sudanese pastoralists were killed by a Dinka militia at an unspecified location in the disputed Twic state (Warrap state, coordinates for Mayen Abun used at prec2).

On April 15, SSPDF clashed with armed pastoralists at Obay in Panyikang county (Upper Nile state; coordinates for Tonga used at prec2). One soldier and four pastoralists were killed. (Note: given the proximity to the border, it is possible the pastoralists were from Sudan, though have been coded as South Sudanese pending further information).

On April 15th, communities from Ajak and Kongdeer once again clashed in the vicinity of Wathmuok (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), following similar clashes over the weekend. Five people were injured in the clashes in a fight which involved basic hand weapons, although the dates in which the injuries occurred are not specified (one event has been recorded for the weekend of the 13th/14th, and a separate event for the 15th). Two officials in the disputed Aweil state government were fired due to alleged involvement in the violence, and security forces have been deployed to the area.

On or before April 16th, unknown gunmen shot dead four individuals (coded as civilians) at an unspecified part of the Tambura-Yambio road (on the side of the disputed Tambura state; coordinates for Diabio, Western Equatoria, used at precision 2). There is no further information.
On April 17th, unknown gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle close to Ajakuac (Warrap state), killing four civilians and wounding five.

On April 18th or 19th, an armed group (believe to come from Obel village in nieghbouring Jonglei attacked an area in Doleib Hill close to Malakal, killing one and wounding four (with the Chief of Doleib Hill among the wounded). The motive for the attack is unknown; five people have been arrested.

On April 19th, an armed group (suspected to be Murle from the disputed Boma state, and coded as such) attacked three civilians in the area of Honygak cattle camp, as they were travelling to Pajiek-Kuei (no geographic information found; coordinates for Jalle, Jonglei state, used at precision 2). Two civilians were killed, and the third escaped. The attackers were also accused of looting NGO vehicles in the area of Jalle and Patiou.

On April 21st, NAS rebels attacked SSPDF soldiers on the road between Goli and Pisak (Central Equatoria). One SSPDF soldier was killed and another was wounded; there is no information on NAS casualties.

On April 22nd, NAS rebels ambushed SSPDF at Kegiko (no geographic information found; coordinates for Yei, Central Equatoria, used at precision 2). One government soldier was killed and two were wounded; there is no information regarding possible NAS casualties.

On April 22nd, an armed group (believed to be from the disputed Tonj state, and coded as such) attacked the village of Uliira (Western Bahr el Ghazal state; no geographic information found, coordinates for Kuajiena used at prec2).
On April 24th, unknown gunmen attacked Khor Jamus (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), killing three. There is no further information.

On April 24th, seven Pari fighters from Lafon county attacked the village of Logiri in Torit county (no geographic information found; coordinates for Longairo, Eastern Equatoria, used at precision 2). The attackers killed one and wounded another.
On April 25th, an unknown group from Mayom county (coded as Bul Nuer militia) attacked the SSPDF barracks in Abiemnom (Unity state), killing two soldiers.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On April 25th, suspected SPLM-IO elements attacked two unspecified locations in Pagol county (Warrap state), killing seven people (coded as civilians) and injuring one.
On April 26th, a University student was allegedly abducted in Juba by SSPDF soldiers, who tortured him before releasing him at an unspecified time (implied to be mid/late June by the source).

On or after April 27th, a state-level MP was reportedly tortured by police in Pagak (Upper Nile state), after he had been arrested by police alongside three other local politicians (actor 1 coded as Police). The state politicians were arrested as part of a power struggle between the governor and deputy governor of the disputed Maiwut state.

On or before April 29th, pastoralists were reported to have beaten five civilians in Magwi county (Eastern Equatoria state). The pastoralists - who are implied to have come from outside of the area - apparently committed the beatings after soldiers shot dead some of their cows.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: During early May (and likely in the weeks before, date of May 1st used at time precision 2) reports emerged of SPLM-IO forces mobilising - and possibly recruiting - in the area of Maluk (Jonglei state, coordinates for Malek used at precision 2), under the command of Generals Simon Gatwech Dual and Duop Lam. The SPLM-IO have denied these reports, saying instead that General Simon Gatwech's presence is related to peace dissemination efforts, and that troops are preparing for cantonment.

On May 2nd, Murle raiders attacked members of the Jie community in the area of Nachumajori in Jebel Boma county, Jonglei state. 15 Murle fighters were killed and two from the Jie were killed, 10 were injured, and 104 women and children have gone missing.

column6: Gok Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On May 2nd, raiders from the Gok Dinka community attacked members of the Pakam community at an unspecified location in Paloich county (coordinates for Paloich, Lakes state, used at precision 2). 445 head of cattle were stolen. Four people were killed (including at least one form the attackers), and eight wounded.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On May 2nd, an SPLM-IO soldier raped a woman at an unspecified location between Maper and Kuok. The soldier was arrested.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column9: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On May 6th, two groups of IDPs (armed with knives and sticks) clashed in a camp at the UNMISS Protection of Civilians site in Juba, reportedly over reports that a boy had impregnated a girl from a different clan (note the clan isn't specified; both actors coded as Nuer ethnic group), sparking anger from that family. One person was killed and 36 wounded. [size=dozens]

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: On May 4th, a group of eight men beat a prison warden to death in or near Tirangore (Eastern Equatoria) (attackers coded as rioters). There is no further information on the attack.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On May 4th, a police officer was involved in an exchange of fire with one or more NSS agents in Bor (Jonglei state), wounding an NSS officer. The reason for the clash is unclear.

On May 6th, students and teachers from Rumbek National Secondary School demonstrated in Rumbek (Lakes state), over a lack of lessons, amidst disputes among the senior staff of the school. Police arrested ten students and two teachers. [size=small]

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service; Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On May 7th, a heavy deployment of security personnel (seemingly a combination of SSPDF, SSNPS, and NSS) was reported in Juba, amidst indications that youth anti-govt protests were planned for May 16th. The deployment has been downplayed by the Interior Minister and Inspector General of the Police, saying it is simply part of preparations for the anniversary of the SPLM/A on the 16th.

On or before May 8th, students from the St Mary College for Nursing and Midwifery in Wau (Western Bahr el Ghazal state) demonstrated against unaffordable fees and the cost of food and transport (note the source implies the students are female). Unspecified security forces (likely police) were reported to have arrested two of the students, and beaten an unspecified number of other students. The school was closed following the incident. [size=small]

On May 9th, 21 nurses at the civil hospital in Yirol (Lakes state) demonstrated against a 75% pay cut, due to the withdrawal of funding by an NGO supporting health care costs at the hospital. The nurses reportedly attacked foreign nurses who were not striking, though the report does not mention the number of injured. Police arrested the nurses, before releasing them pending trial two days later. [size=small]

On May 9th, the newly appointed commissioner for Wonduruba county was killed along with three soldiers when his car hit a landmine at an unspecified location on the Lainya-Wonduruba road (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Wonduruba used at precision 2).

column6: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On May 10th, Pakam Dinka raiders attacked at least four cattle camps in Amongpiny county (coded as one event, approximate coordinates from humanitarian map for Roorbar (Lakes state) used at precision 2). Five people were killed in the raids, and hundreds displaced.

On or before May 10th, an off-duty police officer was killed in the area of Molbang (Warrap state). A local official accused SPLM-IO forces of being responsible, but this has not been confirmed (actor 1 coded as UAG).

On or before May 10th, a pastoralist was killed in the area of Molbang (Warrap state). A local official accused SPLM-IO forces of being responsible, but this has not been confirmed (actor 1 coded as UAG).

On May 11th or 12th, an armed group (coded as Tonj communal militia) attacked an unspecified location(s) in Manalor/Manloor county (Warrap state, approx coordinates for Mathiang from humanitarian map used at precision 2). Two children and a woman were killed in the attack, and 161 dwellings torched.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On May 14th, SPLM-IO rebels were alleged to have attacked an SSOA rebel boat at Mandeng (Upper Nile state). It is unclear whether there were injuries/fatalities, though two people were reported to have been abducted, and food items stolen.

On May 15th, South Sudanese staff working with the UN FAO demonstrated outside their workplace in Juba (and possibly in other parts of the country, one event coded pending further information), as part of a dispute over hazard pay. [size=no report]

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Between January and April 2019, SSPDF and NSS forces attacked 15 villages in the Central Equatoria region in areas between Lainya and Yei (both used at precision 2, alongside Girim and Morsak (also at prec2), as Mukaya at prec1). 12 civilians were killed (distributed across 15 events at time prec3) and 7 were wounded. 67 women (of whom 12 were girls) were reported to have been raped during this time by govt forces (including two women in Karpteo and one in Yei).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: During the months of May and June 2019, fighting among SPLM-IO units loyal to rival commanders occurred in or near Maiwut town (Upper Nile state). There are unknown number of fatalities, though the sources notes that ""some civilians"" were killed either during or in retaliation for the fighting. Two events coded at time prec3, with three fatalities apiece.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On May 17th, SPLM-IO soldiers freed a colleague who was being detained in SPLM-IO custody in Dablual (Unity state) for raping a female in Leer, killing one guard in the process.

On May 17th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Kapoeta state) attacked members of the Jie community in the village of Loyapuru (coordinates for Boma, Jonglei state, used at precision 2). Nine people were killed, and one injured.

On 18 May 2019, armed pastoralists from Tonj attacked Lou civilians in Roc Roc Dong (Western Bahr el Ghazal), killing at least two, including a local chief, who's body was then set on fire. Several dwellings were torched, and the village looted.
On May 18th, gunmen killed three traders and another civilian in two separate events at Kpakpadupo on the road from the CAR to Tambura.

On May 19th, a youth militia (implied as coming from the disputed Tonj state, and coded as such) infiltrated Kuajiena town (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), killing four members of a family (including a baby) and wounding one other as they slept.

On May 19th, unknown gunmen attacked a passenger vehicle as it travelled towards Tonj, at an area in Rojrojdong county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state). One person was killed, and two or three injured. One source suggests the attackers had set up an illegal checkpoint.

On or before May 20th, a militia from Haforiere payam in Torit East county attacked Angarama payam in Geria county (coordinates for Lolianga, Eastern Equatoria, used at precision 2). One person was killed in the clashes, and a woman was injured. There is no stated motive for the attack.

On May 20th, President Kiir fired the governors of the disputed Western Lakes, Aweil, Central Upper Nile and Northern Upper Nile states, and announced new replacements via decree. This follows from the firing of the governors of the disputed Ruweng and Southern Liech states on May 14th, again via decree.
On or before May 21st, a pastoralist was killed by an unknown gunman (or gunmen) in Udici county (Western Bahr el Ghazal). One person has been arrested in connection with the incident.

On May 21st, three people were killed by an unknown group on the road between Aweil and Wau, likely in Udici county (Western Bahr el Ghzal). The deaths may be in connection to the killing of a pastoralist in the same area.

On May 21st, a civilian (likely to be of Jur Chol or Fertit ethnicity) was abducted by a Dinka pastoralist militia from the disputed Gogrial state in Bahr-Akol, in retaliation for a killing of their colleague in the area. The abductee was beaten, but was released and turned over to police on May 23rd.

On May 21st, unknown gunmen fired upon a convoy of vehicles belonging to a demining NGO at Nanak-nak bridge on the way to Buno (Eastern Equatoria, coordinates used at precision 2), wounding two staff members.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On May 21st, SPLM-IO soldiers were alleged to have beaten a Paramount Chief and robbed cattle at an unspecified location in Kuajiena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal; coordinates for Kuajiena used at prec2), after he refused to supply them with firearms.

On May 22nd, NAS rebels ambushed SSPDF soldiers at Kejiko (Central Equatoria). Between this and another NAS ambush on 24 May, two SSPDF were killed and eight wounded (fatalities spread across two events).
On or before May 22nd, two people were killed in Agok area to the south of Wau. The killings may be connected to the killing of a pastoralist earlier that week.

On May 24th, NAS rebels ambushed SSPDF soldiers at an unspecified location between Kegulu and Lutaya (Central Equatoria; coordinates for Kegulu used at precision 2). Between this and another NAS ambush on 22 May, two SSPDF were killed and eight wounded (fatalities spread across two events).
On May 24th, an armed group attacked a commercial vehicle at Panpitiya near Mangalla (Central Equatoria, coordinates used). One person was killed, and two children were abducted.

On or before May 25th, youth (suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state, and coded as such) raided 12 head of cattle in Tonj town (Warrap state). The source suggests a number of people were injured in the raid.
On May 26th, gunmen fired at youths herding cattle in the area of Golnyang (Unity state, coordinates for Abiemnom used at precision 2), killing two and wounding one. There is no further information.

column16: South Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On May 26th and 27th, SSPDF and militias allegedly under the command of Cabinet Minister Martin Elia (and coded as Pajullu ethnic militia) attacked NAS positions at an unspecified location between Lainya and Wonduruba counties (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Komandani used at prec2). NAS said they inflicted heavy casualties, and two of their own were wounded. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 and split across two events.

On May 26th, two Ugandan teachers were killed by five gunemn as they travelled to Rumbek from Atiaba, in the area of Pulkuji (Lakes state, coordinates for Aduel used at precision 2). The killing was in revenge for the accidental death of a chief, in a road accident involving a Kenyan national.

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On May 26, nineteen people were killed during clashes at an unspecified location in the disputed Twic state (Warrap state; coordinates for Turalei used at prec2). The attacking group (from the disputed Northern Liech state) are allegedly elements of an ""independent military force"" under Gen Matthew Puljang (and have been coded as Military Forces). 18 people were wounded across the May 26th and 28th events, and an SSPDF commander was killed after his base was overrun. 3,000 head of cattle were stolen.
On May 27th, pupils demonstrated in Rumbek (Lakes state), following the killing of their Ugandan deputy headmaster and teacher the previous day. [size=no report]

column16: Radio Tamazuj; South Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune
column17: On May 26th and 27th, SSPDF and militias allegedly under the command of Cabinet Minister Martin Elia (and coded as Pajullu ethnic militia) attacked NAS positions at an unspecified location between Lainya and Wonduruba counties (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Komandani used at prec2). NAS said they inflicted heavy casualties, and two of their own were wounded. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 and split across two events.

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On May 28th, eight people were killed and wounded during clashes at unspecified locations in Ajakuac, Aweng and Turalei counties of the disputed Twic state (Warrap state). The attacking group (from the disputed Northern Liech state) are allegedly elements of an ""independent military force"" under Gen Matthew Puljang (and have been coded as Military Forces), who lost four soldiers between these events. 18 people were wounded across the May 26th and 28th events, and an SSPDF commander was killed after his base was overrun. 3,000 head of cattle were stolen. (Three events coded at location prec2, with 4 fatalities spread across three events).

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On May 28th, eight people were ""killed and wounded"" during clashes at unspecified locations in Ajakuac, Aweng and Turalei counties of the disputed Twic state (Warrap state). The attacking group (from the disputed Northern Liech state) are allegedly elements of an ""independent military force"" under Gen Matthew Puljang (and have been coded as Military Forces), who lost four soldiers between these events. 18 people were wounded across the May 26th and 28th events, and an SSPDF commander was killed after his base was overrun. 3,000 head of cattle were stolen. (Three events coded at location prec2, with 4 fatalities spread across three events).

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On May 28th, eight people were ""killed and wounded"" during clashes at unspecified locations in Ajakuac, Aweng and Turalei counties of the disputed Twic state (Warrap state). The attacking group (from the disputed Northern Liech state) are allegedly elements of an ""independent military force"" under Gen Matthew Puljang (and have been coded as Military Forces), who lost four soldiers between these events. 18 people were wounded across the May 26th and 28th events, and an SSPDF commander was killed after his base was overrun. 3,000 head of cattle were stolen. (Three events coded at location prec2, with 4 fatalities spread across three events).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On May 29th, nine SPLM-IO soldiers abducted 10 women at Rimenze IDP camp (Western Equatoria), as proxies for their husbands, who were the intended targets for arrest. The women were reported to have been sexually assaulted (though it has yet to be established in what way they were sexually assaulted, except that they were not raped), and one woman was beaten. The women were released the following day when their husbands turned themselves in.

column6: SPLM-FD: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (Former Detainees)
column17: On May 30th, Pagan Amum - de facto leader of the SPLM-FDs - announced that he was no longer part of the faction, and cast doubt on the ability of a reunified SPLM party to effect meaningful change in the party or political system as a whole. No successor has been announced.

column9: Luo Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: In late May or early June Tonj pastoralist militiamen abducted an unspecified number of female children from the Lou ethnic group, in Roc Roc Dong (Western Bahr el Ghazal state).
01 June. Four people have been killed and six wounded in an armed attack by unknown gunmen in Kilo 10 area (Maban), Northern Upper Nile State. [size=no report].

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On or before June 7th, pupils and teachers of Agergum Primary School demonstrated in Rumbek, damaging buildings of the education ministry and looting the market, after teachers from the school were transferred. NSS agents arrested demonstrators, and were alleged to have beaten and tortured them before their release. [size=20]

On or around September 6th, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF (and an unspecified militia, coded as Yei communal militia) attacked their positions but were repulsed, and that that NAS rebels then proceeded to overtaken SSPDF positions at Mukaya and Bereka, Central Equatoria. NAS claimed to kill 25 SSPDF (fatalities spread over two events), and that five rebels were wounded.
