On June 9th, an armed group, reportedly from Manalor county (coded as Tonj militia) attacked the home of a chief in Roc Roc Dong (Western Bahr el Ghazal, approximate coordinates from humanitarian map), killing his son and two others, and wounding between two and five others.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On September 6th, NAS rebels alleged that SPLM-IO troops looted and ""tortured"" the residents in the area of Mangalla, Central Equatoria after fighting between the two rebel groups earlier that day.

On or around September 6th, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF (and an unspecified militia, coded as Yei communal militia) attacked their positions but were repulsed, and that that NAS rebels then proceeded to overtaken SSPDF positions at Mukaya and Bereka, Central Equatoria. NAS claimed to kill 25 SSPDF (fatalities spread over two events), and that five rebels were wounded.
09 June. Unidentified gunmen attacked villagers in Agordit village. The attack left one person injured. Livestock was also killed.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On September 6th, NAS rebels claimed that they repulsed an attack by SPLM-IO rebels near Mangalla (Central Equatoria).
On June 9th, gunmen, allegedly from Maban county, attacked the village of Agordit (Upper Nile state, coordinates for Adar Yeil used at prec2), injuring one person and killing a number of livestock.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Catholic Radio Network
column17: On June 10th, employees of Insight Security (formerly Warrior Security) demonstrated in Juba, in protest at being paid in SSP rather than USD. [size=large]

On June 10th, an NGO vehicle was fired upon by unknown armed group at an unspecified location in between Khat and Boaw (Unity state, coordinates for Lang used at prec2). Two national staff members were wounded.
On June 10th, unidentified gunmen attacked Bangketa village in Jamam county (Upper Nile, coordinates for Jamam town used at prec2). A police officer was killed during the attack.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On June 11th, a South Sudanese court sentenced Peter Biar Ajak to 2 years in prison in relation to an attempted jail break at the NSS detention facility in Oct 2018, and Kerbino Wol to 15 years. Five others were sentenced to 5 years.

column16: Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On June 12th, students at the Royal High School in Bor (Jonglei state) demonstrated in response to a lack of food and poor standards in the school, setting several buildings ablaze. Police shot and wounded two demonstrators, who injured four or five police through throwing stones. [size=small]

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 12 June 2019, primary and secondary school students demonstrated in Bor (Jonglei state), following a dispute between themselves and their school administrators over the food they receive. Police and an unspecified security force (implied to be NSS) fired live rounds at the students, wounding two students (one who was 11 years-old) who were not involved in the demonstrations. [size=no report]
On or before June 12th, employees of Insight Security (formerly Warrior Security) demonstrated in Rumbek, in protest at being paid in SSP rather than USD. [size=no report]

On June 15th, two national NGO employees were beaten and dragged from their vehicles by a group of villagers (coded as rioters) at an unspecified location in Eastern Equatoria (coordinates for Torit used at prec3). The victims were reportedly targeted by the villagers because of their perceived ethnicity, though the convoy was later released. [size=no report]

During the month of June, South Sudanese raiders (residing in Uganda as refugees) attacked and looted several villages in Magwi payam (Eastern Equatoria, coordinates used at prec2), killing two and wounding many.

On June 16th, a pastoralist militia suspected of coming from the disputed Tonj state (and coded as such) attacked an unspecified village in Roc Roc Dong county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), killing 11, and burning dwellings.

On June 18th, a child was abducted by an unidentified group of armed men, at an unspecified location in Lafon county along the Lafon-Juba road (Eastern Equatoria, coordinates for Lafon used at prec2).

On June 19th, two South Sudanese INGO employees were shot and wounded by what the source describes as ""a community member"" (coded as Jonglei communal militia) in Patluak village (Jonglei state). The perpetrator reportedly mistook the two aid workers for ""his enemies"". The attacker was arrested, and the two aid workers were treated at a nearby clinic.
On June 19th, two hunters were killed in the area of Dambala (Jonglei state, coordinates for Ajwara used at prec2), by an unknown armed group.
During the week commencing June 17th, a woman was killed by unknown gunmen in Dongoro (Central Equatoria state). Four people have been arrested in connection with the attack.
